entry.title: SAP TechEd2025-XP264- Explore how to run cloud-native applications on SAP BTP, Kyma runtime
entry.content:
Description

A sneak preview of the material for the SAP TechEd 2025 session catalog number XP264 - Explore how to run cloud-native applications on SAP BTP, Kyma runtime.

  • Day-2 Operations: Management, Maintenance, Monitoring, and Optimization
  • Technical connectivity to public and private (on-premise) systems

The repository with the session material will be made available publicly on Monday, November 3rd.

See you there in Messe Berlin, Messedamm 22, 14055 Berlin, room 504, Hall 5.2, on November 06, 2025 09:00 AM CEST!

 

Overview

This session introduces attendees to Day-2 operations with SAP BTP, Kyma runtime - a managed kubernetes environment to help connect and extend enterprise applications in the cloud-native world.

In a nutshell, SAP BTP, Kyma Runtime (SKR) is a managed k8s runtime environment with a kubernetes cluster based on Gardener and a set of building blocks called Kyma modules.

Each instance of SAP BTP Kyma runtime environment is a single k8s gardener cluster with its own set of kyma modules.
Subsequently, all these clusters are managed by a central Kyma Control Plane (KCP) that orchestrates the lifecycle of

  • the underlying hyperscaler project,
  • the Gardener Cluster,
  • and the Kyma modules.

 

 

During the session you will learn

  • how to operate applications with SAP BTP, Kyma runtime and discover the power of smooth integration with cloud applications and on-premise systems using the advanced connectivity features.
  • to explore operational best practices from mastering troubleshooting techniques and intelligent root-cause analysis to event-driven autoscaling that adapts to your business needs in real time.
  • about BTP multitenant applications with SAP BTP, Kyma runtime.

Requirements

The requirements to follow the exercises in this repository are...

Important

  • You must be able to fork the repository and activate the github actions at the fork. This is mandatory for this session!
  • Thus, you may need a GitHub user.
    If you haven't got one yet, please sign-up on GitHub before the workshop or at the very beginning of the session.

Important

The session content is provided exclusively on the SAP-Samples github, and many excercises have been implemented as CI/CD Github Actions worflows (GHA).

Security is paramount. With the Github Action IDP-delegated flow, there is no more need to provide kubernetes and btp credentials when using github actions.

  • âœ…The Github Action workflows acting as the OIDC provider.

  • âœ…All the kubernetets environments in the landscape are configured to trust GitHubâ€™s token identity provider. They come with the pre-configured OIDC applications leveraging the built-in Gardener OIDC shoot extension.

  • âœ…SAP Cloud Identity Services acting as a platform IDP on the BTP side of the house has been federated with the Github actions OIDC Provider

  • âœ…As a result, the very short-lived credentials are being fetched and rotated automatically on the behalf of the repository user for both kubernetes and btp platform operations.

  • The good news is you may run the GHA-based exercises directly, from your forked repository, in a browser on the provided teched laptop.

Disclaimer

Personal devices should not be used for this session. Hands-on session participants will be using Windows laptops provided by the organizers.

entry.title: SAP MDG: Locking Supplier General Data When Data Already exists
entry.content:
Hi SCN Folks, 

Hope you guys are doing great ðŸ™‚

Note 01: This blog does not include execution screenshots.
Note 02: The entire code was developed and validated in the SANDBOX system, with results meeting expectations.
Note 03: There are several ways to implement; this blog is written about one of them.

Create one custom class & redefine the standard class (CL_MDG_BS_ECC_HANDLER)

Method Responsible: IF_MDG_BS_BP_ACCESS_HANDLER~GET_ENTITY_PROPERTIES.

DATA: lv_crequest_type TYPE usmd_crequest_type,
      lv_cr_number     TYPE usmd_crequest,
      lo_app_context   TYPE REF TO if_usmd_app_context.

DATA: lo_data      TYPE REF TO data,
      lt_data      TYPE usmd_ts_data_entity,
      lt_msg       TYPE usmd_t_message,
      ls_msg       TYPE usmd_s_message,
      lt_erp_v     TYPE REF TO data.

FIELD-SYMBOLS:
      <lt_erpv> TYPE SORTED TABLE,
      <ls_erpv> TYPE any,
      <lv_erpv> TYPE any.

CALL METHOD cl_usmd_app_context=>get_context
  RECEIVING
    eo_context = lo_app_context.

IF lo_app_context IS BOUND.

  CALL METHOD lo_app_context->get_attributes
    IMPORTING
      ev_crequest_id   = lv_cr_number
      ev_crequest_type = lv_crequest_type
      ev_process       = lv_process.

  lv_crequest_type = iv_crequest_type.

  CALL METHOD super->if_mdg_bs_bp_access_handler~get_entity_properties
    EXPORTING
      iv_entity         = iv_entity
      is_key            = is_key
      io_model          = io_model
      iv_crequest_type  = iv_crequest_type
      iv_crequest_step  = iv_crequest_step
      iv_crequest_index = iv_crequest_index
    CHANGING
      cf_read_only      = cf_read_only.

  IF iv_crequest_type EQ 'ZMDGS03'.
    io_model->read_entity_data_all(
      EXPORTING
        i_fieldname      = 'BP_HEADER'
        if_active        = abap_false
        i_crequest       = lv_cr_number
      IMPORTING
        et_message       = lt_msg
        et_data_entity   = lt_data
    ).

    lt_erp_v = VALUE #(
      lt_data[ usmd_entity      = 'BP_HEADER'
               usmd_entity_cont = 'BP_VENGEN'
               struct           = 'KATTR' ]-r_t_data OPTIONAL ).

    IF lt_erp_v IS NOT INITIAL.
      IF iv_entity EQ 'BP_VENGEN'.
        cf_read_only = 'X'.
      ENDIF.
    ENDIF.
  ENDIF.

ENDIF.

SAP S/4HANA   SAP Master Data Governance   ABAP Development  

Thank You, 
Sandeep Suggu.

entry.title: End-to-End Shell Copy Scenario in Software Provisioning Manager (SWPM) 1.0
entry.content:
• Introduction
  • Step 1: System Export
  • 1. Download the Latest SWPM:
  • 2. Start SWPM & Select Scenario
  • 3. Set Source System Parameters
  • 4. Trigger Export with SUM 2.0
  • 5. Transfer Export Directory
  • Step 2: System Provisioning (Import on Target Host)
  • 1. Prepare Target Database
  • 2. Install ASCS Instance
  • 3. Provide SAPEXE Kernel and SAP Host Agent Binaries
  • 4. Import Database Shell Instance
  • 5. Install the Stub Primary Application Server (PAS)
  • Step 3: Post-Copy Activities
  • Tips & Recommendations
  • Useful Links

 

Introduction

Shell Copy is a new scenario introduced in SWPM 1.0 to support digital transformation with SAP Business Transformation Center.  For more information, see [Everything about using SAP Business Transformation center for SDT S/4 HANA Conversion 2023 from ECC].  

The shell copy scenario helps you prepare an SAP ERP shell system containing all Dictionary and Repository objects and all Customizing - while excluding application data. For more insights, please see the introductory blog: [Reducing the DataBase Size of SAP ERP Systems Using Shell Copy Scenario]. 

Below, you'll find an example workflow that demonstrates a typical Shell Copy procedure using SWPM 1.0 for SAP ERP 6.0 EHP8 on Linux. The process consists of three main phases: system export, system provisioning, and post-copy steps.  

IMPORTANT: Always consult the latest SAP product documentation and Shell Copy Guide specific to your operating system and database platform. Review and apply all relevant SAP Notes before starting the Shell Copy scenario on your landscape. 

 

Step 1: System Export

1. Download the Latest SWPM:  
  • Obtain the latest SWPM 1.0 for NW higher than 7.0x SAR file supporting Shell Copy from SAP Software Center. 
  • Review prerequisites: "Running Software Provisioning Manager". 
2. Start SWPM & Select Scenario 
  • In the Product Catalog, select: SAP Business Suite 7i 2016 â†’ EHP8 for SAP ERP 6.0 ABAP â†’ <DB Type> â†’ Shell Copy â†’ Source System â†’ Database Instance Shell Export 

 

3. Set Source System Parameters 
  • Confirm or enter the path to the SAP ECC profile folder 

  • Enter <sid> adm password when prompted. 

 

  • Provide the DDIC userâ€™s password in client 000 (needed for online preparation). 

4. Trigger Export with SUM 2.0 
  • In the Shell Copy scenario, Software Update Manager (SUM) 2.0 replaces Migration Monitor for database migration. 

  • Specify the export directory path where SWPM will extract and run SUM. 
  • Download and provide the latest SUM 2.0 archive from the SAP Software Center. 

  • Confirm the â€œParameter Summaryâ€ dialog to trigger exports. 
5. Transfer Export Directory 
  • When export is completed, copy the entire export directory to the target host (including SUM and data). 

Step 2: System Provisioning (Import on Target Host) 

1. Prepare Target Database 
  • Set up the target database per the installation guide for SAP ERP 6.0. Under â€œProduct Releaseâ€, make sure that you select â€œSAP NetWeaver 7XX-basedâ€. 
  • Tip: Review and apply required SAP Notes required for Shell Copy 
    that resolve known issues. 
2. Install ASCS Instance 
  • Start SWPM 1.0 on the target and choose:â€¨SAP Business Suite 7i 2016 â†’ EHP8 for SAP ERP 6.0 ABAP â†’ <DB Type> â†’ Shell Copy â†’ Target System â†’ ASCS Instance 
  • The SAP system ID (SAPSID) must remain the same between source and target (e.g., if source is SC1, target must also be SC1). 
  • In that example we provide a Master Password for all system users such, e.g. <sid>adm, SAPService<SAPSID>. If you did not create the operating system users manually before the installation, the Software Provisioning Manager creates them with the common Master Password. If users are not pre-created, SWPM will create them. 
  • For master password requirements, refer to he SAP System Parameters section of the installation guide. 
3. Provide SAPEXE Kernel and SAP Host Agent Binaries 
  • SWPM will prompt for SAPEXE Kernel archive and the SAP Host Agent binary files - have them ready. 
4. Import Database Shell Instance 
  • On the target DB host, launch SWPM and select:â€¨SAP Business Suite 7i 2016 â†’ EHP8 for SAP ERP 6.0 ABAP â†’ <DB Type> â†’ Shell Copy â†’ Target System â†’ Database Shell Instance 
  • For standard installation (all instances on one host), /sapmnt/ is local and SWPM will detect profile directory. 
  • Use the previously set master password and <sid>adm password 
  • Enter the same DBSID as used in the source system.
  • Provide the required SAP Kernel resources
  • Specify the SUM export directory path you copied earlier. 
  • Note: If changing CPU architecture (e.g., Windows to Linux), provide the appropriate SUM.SAR for the new OS on the target system

  • Address any DB-specific dialogs without making unsupported changes to the DB layer. 
5. Install the Stub Primary Application Server (PAS) 
  • Launch SWPM and choose:â€¨SAP Business Suite 7i 2016 â†’ EHP8 for SAP ERP 6.0 ABAP â†’ <DB Type> â†’ Shell Copy â†’ Target System â†’ Stub Primary Application Server Instance 
  • Specify the instance profile folder. 
  • Use the previously set master password. 
  • Provide archives for SAPEXE, IGSEXE, and IGSHelper as requested. 
  • Address any DB-specific dialogs. 
  • Once the PAS instance installation has been completed, the Shell ABAP system should be up and running. 

Step 3: Post-Copy Activities 

The last step is to prepare the Shell ERP system as described in the Follow-Up Activities section of the Shell Copy Guide for your operating system and platform. 

Tips & Recommendations 
  • Prepare required SAP Notes in advance to avoid interruptions. 
  • Use the latest supported versions of SWPM and SUM. 
  • Avoid DB layer changes between source and target unless explicitly supported by SAP. 
  • Master passwords should comply with all OS-level security policies. 
Useful Links 
  • SAP Software Center 
  • Shell Copy Guide 
  • Post-Copy Activities 
  • SAP Notes required for Shell Copy 
  • â€œReducing DB Size of SAP ERP systems via Shell Copy Scenarioâ€ 

By following these steps, you can efficiently perform a shell copy of your SAP ERP landscape using SWPM 1.0 and SUM 2.0.

entry.title: SAP User Experience Update: Whatâ€™s New for SAP S/4HANA 2025 (Private Cloud and On-Premise)
entry.content:
SAP S/4HANA 2025 comes with a whole host of user experience innovations and improvements.  Web access via My Home and the SAP Fiori launchpad has many useful improvements, as does SAP Mobile Start for mobile access. Joule gives conversational access to Private Cloud Edition using natural language, now also with analytical insights. There are additional collaboration capabilities, and many improvements in details: some towards providing a more consistent and integrated SAP Business Suite, some simply making a userâ€™s life easier. Finally, design and UI technology is also advancing, with powerful AI support for developers now available.

This post covers:

  • UX Updates for Consistent and Integrated Business Suite
  • Web access: My Home and SAP Fiori launchpad
  • Mobile access: SAP Mobile Start
  • Joule
  • Situation Handling news
  • AI-Assisted capabilities: outlook
  • New collaboration capabilities
  • UX improvements in details
  • UI adaptation improvements for key users
  • Design and Technology news

If you want to get an impression of how good SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, looks across all the main product areas, have a look at the online Product Tour.

Since this post covers whatâ€™s new, building on the previous 2023 release, you might want to have a look at the UX innovations which came with the Feature Pack Stacks 00, 01 and 02 of the 2023 release:

  • SAP User Experience Update: Whatâ€™s New for SAP S/4HANA 2023 (Private Cloud and On-Premise).
  • User Experience Advances with SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS01 (Private Cloud and On-Premise).
  • SAP User Experience Q4/2024 News for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2023.

For a full overview of whatâ€™s new since the FPS00 shipment of the 2023 release, have a look at the documentation (note that it includes features from the above 2023 FPS01 and FPS02 blog posts, as well as this one):

  • Whatâ€™s New for SAP Fiori launchpad for SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

 

UX Updates for Consistent and Integrated Business Suite

We aim to provide a consistent and integrated experience for all users of the SAP Business Suite, which means providing an entry point for users to access all the various SAP products within the suite, and ensuring that the user experience across these products is consistent, making it easy for users to use applications from different products.

Entry Points

Figure 1 shows our approach for providing a web and a native mobile entry point to the products of the suite, such as SAP S/4HANA Cloud. Iâ€™d like to highlight that Joule can also be seen as an entry point to access the entire suite, since our goal is to provide Joule wherever you are, be it in our web applications or native mobile apps. Using Joule, our goal is to allow users to query and perform actions on all the products and applications which they are authorized to use, simply using natural language. As youâ€™ll see below, we are making good progress towards this goal.

Figure 1: Entry points providing an integrated workplace for accessing the SAP Business Suite. Alt Text: Image showing Joule on the left, â€œavailable web and mobileâ€, and on the right a diagram with boxes indicating that SAP Mobile Start, SAP Start, and SAP Build Work Zone provide central access to SAP, with three boxes below for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, SAP SuccessFactors and Other SAP Products.

Web Central Access

I have covered recent UX innovations in our web central entry points, such as SAP Start and SAP Build Work Zone, and central services such as SAP Task Center, in my recent cloud UX blog posts. Since these capabilities also apply to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition as well as SAP S/4HANA (except for SAP Start), I will not repeat them here, but rather refer you to them:

  • SAP User Experience Q1/2025 Update â€“ Part 1: Many New Innovations Available (AI, Joule and More).
  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update â€“ Part 1: AI, Joule, SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Mobile Start.

 What we will look at in this post in detail are UX innovations for local access from web or mobile, via My Home and the SAP Fiori launchpad, and via SAP Mobile Start. Each has a dedicated section further below.

Design Updates for Suite Consistency

To achieve consistency across the suite, we have made design improvements which are relevant for a consistent user experience across the entire SAP Business Suite, and which are now available with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025 and SAP S/4HANA 2025. As I mentioned in my April blog post Upcoming Design Updates for the SAP Business Suite (SAP Fiori for Web), consistency of the user experience across the various applications used by a user is an important part of overall usability, helping users to feel confident and at ease when using a suite of products â€“ no unexpected surprises.

In this section, weâ€™ll look at four design updates provided by the SAP Fiori launchpad, as well as examples of the new design for illustrations:

  • Navigation menu: Side navigation
  • Updated shell bar
  • Updated user menu
  • Updated notifications
  • New illustrations design

Navigation Menu: Side Navigation

Many SAP products already offer a navigation menu on the left of the screen, a pattern already familiar to many people. Hence, we have decided to apply that approach to navigation across the SAP Business Suite in upcoming releases.

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA, the side navigation is displayed as an overlay, as you can see in Figure 2. It gives you direct access to your favorite apps, either directly or via the folders you have created. It also gives you direct access to your Spaces and Pages. The previously available menu to access all your spaces and pages along with personalization options is available via the entry â€œAll Spacesâ€ at the bottom of the menu.

A big benefit of this new navigation menu is that you can now access your favorite apps directly from any application. Previously, you would have to return to My Home and then click on your favorite app, now you can access it directly from the menu, as shown in Figure 2.

Figure 2: The new navigation menu, opened up from the new shell bar, showing direct access to Favourite Apps, My Spaces and All Spaces. Alt Text: an image showing a list of sales orders and on the left a pop-over with a navigation menu with the sections already mentioned. Below the â€œFavourite Appâ€ eight apps are listed as well as two folders for favorite apps, plus the folder â€œInsightsâ€ for the insight tiles.

New Shell Bar â€“ need to switch it on!

The new shell bar design for the SAP Business Suite is available for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. The immediately visible difference is that now the product name is displayed to the right of the SAP Logo, in this case â€œS/4HANA Cloudâ€ as you can see at the top of Figure 2. The logo and the name are all contained within a clickable area, which brings the user to the start page (e.g. My Home).

The new shell bar enables the next two design updates to the user menu and to notifications.

By default, after upgrading, the old shell bar will be shown, with the new navigation menu. We advise that you check any test automation and RPA (Robotic Process Automation) you may have before switching on the new shell bar, since you may need to make some adjustments â€“ in particular if you log off at the end of a test.

You can switch on the new shell bar via the Activate New Features application, with the feature â€œ/UI2/SHELL_BAR_TOGGLEâ€.

Updated User Menu

The new user menu design shown in Figure 3 provides more space for the avatar of the user, and provides more space between items for easier selection. The settings are always at the top as the first entry, and the â€œSign Outâ€ option is separated from the actual navigation options in the list, to make it easier to find.

 Figure 3: Updated design of user menu and notifications. Alt Text: On the left an image of the previous user menu and the updated user menu. On the right an image of the updated notifications list, showing four notifications in the group â€œLast Monthâ€, each with a title, two lines of description and a line with the data and a â€œmoreâ€ link.

Updated Notifications Design

The new simplified design of notifications shown on the right in Figure 3 fits better with the overall design of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA, and provides simpler interactions. By default notifications are sorted by date, with grouping by â€œTodayâ€, â€œYesterdayâ€, â€œLast Weekâ€, â€œLast Monthâ€. Users can also choose to sort by importance.

All Data Dictionary Help Texts Available to Users

This feature was requested by many customers, and I am happy to announce that it is now available: all the help texts for individual fields which are stored in the back-end data dictionary are now available to users using the built-in help, powered by SAP Companion. In other words, users of SAP Fiori apps have access to the same help texts as were shown with the classic UIs such as SAP GUI. You can see an example in Figure 22.

Figure 22: Data Dictionary help texts now available in SAP Fiori apps. Alt Text: The Manage Purchase Contracts screen is shown, with question marks next to all fields and column headers. On the right the Help Topics are listed, with the Purchase Contract Number selected. Next to the corresponding column header a popover shows the definition text.

Documentation of Keyboard Shortcuts within Applications

Power users are often quicker when only using the keyboard, rather than switching back and forth between keyboard and mouse â€“ but only if they know all the relevant keyboard shortcuts. With the 2508 release we provide information about available keyboard shortcuts directly where you need them, in the context of the application. By selecting â€œKeyboard Shortcutsâ€ in the user menu, a new window appears explaining all the available shortcuts for the application area currently in focus. If you click on a different part of the application, or navigate somewhere else, then the window showing the available shortcuts is updated immediately for the new context.

Figure 23 shows an example for Manage Journal Entries, where the focus is currently on the filter bar. Clicking on the the table results in many more shortcuts being shown, for example for the arrow keys for moving up and down etc., as shown in Figure 24.

Figure 23: In-context documentation of keyboard shortcuts, for the filter bar. Alt Text: A screenshot of the app â€œManage Journal Entriesâ€ with the focus on the filter bar, with a second window on the right containing Keyboard Shortcuts in two groups, â€œGlobal Shortcutsâ€ and â€œGeneric Keyboard Interactionsâ€.

Figure 24: In-context documentation of keyboard shortcuts, for the table. Alt Text: A screenshot of the app â€œManage Journal Entriesâ€ with the focus on the table, with a second window on the right containing Keyboard Shortcuts in two groups, â€œGlobal Shortcutsâ€ and â€œJournal Entries (43,854)â€. The latter contains descriptions for shortcuts for the table, such as the arrow up, down, left, right keys, or using â€œCmd + Dâ€ to delete.

Automatic Update of SAP Fiori Apps Upon Change of Data in Backend

There are quite a few cases where users would appreciate seeing absolutely up-to-date data in their application, so that the data is automatically updated if changes occur in the backend. These changes could be made by other users, or by automated background processing . An example for the latter is the Traceability Results application, which is now automatically updated if a batch run has created new traceability items.

Note that this only supported by applications built with SAP Fiori elements using OData V4.

Improved performance for scrolling in grid tables

Our engineers have done some magic so that now scrolling is very fast in grid tables, which are the table type typically used for working with large volumes of data.

Why do I call it magic? Well, modern web-based UIs have the UI layer running in the browser, managing direct user interactions, and calling services in the backend to get and update data. However, if you are working with a list of say over 100,000 items, you would have to wait quite a long time when starting the application until all items have been loaded into the browser. Hence we only load a certain number to start with, such as 100. This however means that when a user scrolls beyond the 100 which have been loaded, additional data needs to be fetched from the backend, which slows down scrolling. Now, our engineers have found a way to minimize this effect to almost zero, so that you have fast scrolling all the time â€“ magic!

Figure 25: Performance improvement for scrolling in grid tables. Alt Text: a short video showing scrolling through a grid table.

Whenever the threshold is reached and more data needs to be loaded, there is a very short delay, with the progress indicator being shown for a few milliseconds, as you can see in Figure 25. In most cases, this is completely negligible. Nevertheless, we do also provide customers the option to change the number of entries loaded by default when the application is started. This is useful if a customer knows that, for a certain application, the number of entries will not exceed 2.000 for example. Then they can set the threshold to 2.000, which means that the application will take a little bit longer to load first time around, but then scrolling will be instantaneous for all the data. Figure 26 shows the UI for doing this, as part of UI adaptation. The â€œThresholdâ€ determines the maximum number of entries loaded when the application is started, the â€œScroll Thresholdâ€ determines the maximum number that are loaded during scrolling if new entries need to be fetched.

Figure 26: UI adaptation to determine the threshold determining the maximum number of entries loaded in a table when an application is started. Alt Text: A screenshot with a pop-over â€œConfigure Tableâ€ with two new fields â€œThresholdâ€, being edited with the value 3000, and â€œScroll Thresholdâ€, containing the value 300.

Table Grouping and/or â€œShow more per rowâ€ State can be Shared

If a user personalizes a table by grouping entries by one of the fields, such as the date, this grouping is persisted when sharing the link with a colleague: when the colleague opens the application with the link, they see the same grouping applied.

Similarly, if â€œshow more per rowâ€ was selected by the user before sharing the link, the recipient will also see more information per row upon opening the application via the link. This information is also stored when saving a view of a table.

Sort or Group Tables by ID or Description

SAP Fiori apps display the ID and the description in the same column within a table, which provides a better experience than having them in two separate columns.

Now, we offer users a choice when sorting or grouping the table by a column which contains both ID and description: they can choose to do this by ID or by description. As you can see in Figure 27, this selection is very intuitive. The example shows what it looks like when sorting by Company Code. At the bottom of the table you see an entry â€œ1710 (BestRun US)â€, where the Company Code (the ID) is 1710 and the Company Name (the Description) is â€œBestRun USâ€. In the popover â€œSort Byâ€ section, the row of icons next to Company Code and Company Name indicate that currently no sorting is active, with the option to sort either bei Code or by Name ascending or descending.

Figure 27: Sort or group tables by ID (in this case Company Code) or by Description (Company Name) when both are displayed together in one column . Alt Text: A screenshot of part of the Manage Journal Entries app, with a list of journal entries and a pop-over â€œColumn Settingsâ€ with two sections â€œSort Byâ€ and â€œGroup Byâ€. The â€œSort Byâ€ section has two lines, â€œCompany Codeâ€ and â€œCompany Nameâ€, and offers three buttons with icons for each of these, representing â€œno sortingâ€, â€œascendingâ€, â€œdescendingâ€.

Hiding Description Fields in List of Fields in Table Settings

For tables as above where ID and description are displayed in one column, technically, the ID and description are stored in two different fields. Until now, when users personalize the table, both the ID and the description were listed in the list of columns, which confused some users.

Now, we have addressed this by providing the option to hide the descriptions (see Figure 28), and hence simplifying personalization. This option is on by default, i.e. the description fields are automatically hidden now.

Figure 28: Description fields can be hidden from the list of fields shown when personalizing tables. Alt Text: A screenshot with a pop-over â€œView Settingsâ€ containing tabs â€œColumnsâ€, â€œSortâ€, â€œFilterâ€, and a pop-over â€œFiltersâ€ with two options â€œHide descriptionsâ€ (selected) and â€œHide Unselectedâ€ (deselected) . â€œColumnsâ€ is selected and shows a list of columns with check marks. The third entry is â€œCompany Codeâ€, followed by â€œCreated Onâ€ â€“ i.e. the description column â€œCompany Nameâ€ is not listed next to the â€œCompany Codeâ€.

These are the highlights of our changes in details. For the full list of whatâ€™s new since the FPS00 shipment of the 2023 release, have a look at the Whatâ€™s New Viewer:

  • Whatâ€™s New for SAP Fiori launchpad for SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

 

UI adaptation improvements for key users

We have made significant enhancements to UI Adaptation for key users with the 2025 release. The â€œAdapt UIâ€ option which key users see in their user menu shows you what you can change in the app, in a very intuitive way. And you can change and adapt far more than in the past. See below for some highlights.

Also good to know: the Adapt UI menu entry is also available when using a Classic app (SAP GUI for HTML) from within the SAP Fiori launchpad. It will bring up the Adapt UI app for Screen Personas F5740 Adapt UI for Classic Applications with Screen Personas, which allows key users to adapt the layout of these classic UIs.

Key Users Can Rearrange ID and Description Within a Field or Column

SAP applications come with a standard arrangement of ID and description within a field or a column, based on user research. We have found that for financial users, it is usually best to have the ID first and the description in brackets: Company Code (Company Description), for example â€œ1710 (BestRun US)â€ as shown in Figure 27. For users in sales and logistics, it is usually best to have the name first and the ID in brackets: for example Customer Name (Customer ID), for example â€œUS Specialty Cycles 5 (USCU_S05)â€ as shown in Figure 2.

Now, key users can use UI adaptation to rearrange the order for a given application. Doing this change applies then to all occurrences of the field in the application, i.e. the filter bar, the table or in a form on an object page.

Far More Options for Key Users to Adapt UIs

Key users can now make far more significant changes to UIs than before. For example, they can add a button to clear all filter values in the filter bar, remove buttons such as the â€œExport to Excelâ€, and much more. Figure 29 shows the options for configuring a table for example.

Figure 29: Many more options for Key Users to adapt UIs. Alt Text: UI Adaptation is shown switched on for the application Manage Bank Hierarchies, with a popover called â€œConfigure Tableâ€ filling half the screen, and showing 12 options such as â€œEnable Table Exportâ€, â€œFrozen Column Countâ€ with a field for entering the number, â€œSortingâ€, â€œColumnsâ€ etc.

 

Design and Technology News

For a comprehensive overview of the recent design and technology news, have a look at my blog posts from Q1 and Q3 2025. These are also relevant for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA 2025 release, since the design and technology are already available in the cloud:

  • SAP User Experience Q1/2025 Update â€“ Part 7: UI Design and Technology for Web and Mobile
  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update â€“ Part 7: UI Design and Technology for Web and Mobile
    Note though that the SAP Build Extensibility Wizard presented there is currently only integrated with for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

We are progressing at such a pace, that I have some additional news to share with you, not covered by the above posts. In addition, I would like to explicitly mention some particular highlights here from the above posts too.

Regarding extensibility: do have a look at the new SAP Extensibility Explorer.

SAP Design System Portal and UI Kits â€“ now with AI Components

We recently introduced the new SAP Design System portal that brings together the product design guidelines SAP Fiori for web, SAP Fiori for iOS, and SAP Fiori for Android, as well as to the new digital design system guidelines. With its enhanced usability, simplified versioning and improved performance, designers (and developers!) get a better user experience compared with the previous SAP Fiori design guidelines.

The new UI Kits available for designers in Figma make it easy for designers to design accessible UIs at enterprise scale, for web applications, mobile iOS and Android applications as well as wearables. The UI Kits provide reusable components for web and mobile, along with web floorplans, which give you what you need out-of-the-box.

We have just released SAP Web UI Kit v8.0 which includes a full set of AI components: AI Button, AI Menu Button, AI Split Menu Button, AI Prompt Input, AI Input, AI Text Area, and AI Rich Text Editor.

Figure 30: The SAP Design System portal start page (on the left), and SAPâ€™s UI Kits for designers in Figma (on the right). Alt Text: Two screenshots. The portal page shows four main sections SAP Fiori for Web, â€¦ for Android, â€¦ for iOS, and SAP Digital Design System, each followed by links to UI elements, Figma kits, and overviews. The UI Kits show 8 cards, SAP Fiori for Android, Web, iOS, watchOS, Wear OS, Performance, Accessibility and SAP S/4HANA.

Find out more here:

  • New SAP Design System Portal for SAP Fiori Design Guidelines, and New UI Kits for Designers.

SAP Fiori Development Portal

Iâ€™m also happy to inform you about the new SAP Fiori development portal, introduced a few weeks ago. It is designed to help developers maximize the benefits of SAP Fiori elements for OData V4, which is more than just a UI framework: itâ€™s a metadata-driven approach that leverages the SAP Design System as its guiding principle, incorporating the most relevant design system options for typical business tasks.

Figure 31: The SAP Fiori development portal. Alt text: A screenshot showing the Introduction page. On the left a menu has entries Using the Portal, Building Blocks, Global Patterns, Floorplans, SAP Fiori Tools. The Introduction page has a full width card â€œBuilding Blocksâ€ at the top, with a description and tiles representing various building blocks. Below that â€œChoose Your Optionâ€ heading above two side-by-side cards for â€œFloorplansâ€ and â€œCustomer Layoutâ€, each with an image and description, and a â€œLearn Moreâ€ button.

The SAP Fiori development portal puts building blocks front and center. These building blocks - such as tables, forms, filter bars, and charts - are orchestrated by SAP Fiori elements and form the basis of every OData V4 application. They provide standardized layouts and interaction patterns, ensuring UI consistency and boosting developer productivity. The great advantage of using building blocks is that you can use them to create a customer layout and yet still benefit from the advantages of the metadata driven approach: low code, built in enterprise-grade capabilities such as multi-language support, accessibility, security and performance, and design system consistency.

Find out more in this six-part series of blog posts, here is the first one, which contains links to the others:

  • Introducing the SAP Fiori Development Portal: Your Gateway to Rapid SAP Fiori App Creation (1 of 6).

Using AI to Develop UIs

The above posts from Q1/2025 and Q3/2025 introduced a number of powerful ways to accelerate UI development by using AI, such as:

  • Creating SAP Fiori elements apps from a sketch (in the Q1 post), now integrated in SAP Build Code and Joule (Q3 post)
  • Joule for SAPUI5 freestyle development (Q1 post)
  • AI-assisted auto-fix of coding errors with UI5 linter (Q3 post)

Recently, we have gone even further and introduced MCP servers for freestyle SAPUI5 development as well as for developing with SAP Fiori elements and the associated building blocks. These open-source Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers provide AI agents with comprehensive UI5 and SAP Fiori elements knowledge, including best practices and project-aware context information, and thus provide developers with valuable support. Figure 32 shows examples. 

Figure 32: Examples of the UI5 MCP Server (on the left) and the MCP Server for SAP Fiori (on the right) in action. Alt Text: both images show screenshots of a CLINE console view with a task entered as text at the top, followed by a list of steps which the system proposes to do to solve the task.

 Read about these new MCP servers in these blog posts:

  • UI5 MCP Server.
  • MCP Server for SAP Fiori.

Accessibility taken to the next level: WCAG 2.2 support

Accessibility is key to using SAP's business solutions. Adopting the latest standards gives applications a true cutting edge, ensuring that solutions are inclusive and meet the diverse needs of users globally. When creating apps with SAP Build and SAPUI5, developers can leverage the latest Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.2.

For example, two of the key new requirements in the 2.2 version are:

  • The minimum target size of an interactive element now needs to be 24x24 px, so that users donâ€™t accidentally activate a neighbouring element.
  • Each operation that can be performed by dragging can also be performed alternatively without dragging â€“ so that people who cannot use a mouse to drag can still use the UI.

See more details:

  • SAPUI5 is Leading the Way in Accessibility with WCAG 2.2 

Blue Crystal and Belize Themes No Longer Available in the Web

As announced in April (Upcoming Removal of SAP Fiori Themes Belize and Blue Crystal), the visual themes Blue Crystal and Belize have been removed from our web UI technology with the 2025 release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA.

 After upgrading, existing usages of Belize or Blue Crystal will be automatically redirected to the Horizon theme.

If you have created your own custom theme based on Belize or Blue Crystal using the UI theme designer, you will need to migrate this to an available theme. Our strong recommendation is to base the new version on the Horizon theme.

For more information about the web UI technologies affected, and how to migrate custom themes, have a look at this blog post:

  • Announcement: Removal of Belize theme of SAP Fiori.

Note that SAP GUI for Windows continues to support older themes, including Blue Crystal and Belize.

 

Final words

Come join us at TechEd 2025, November 4 - 6, either virtually or in Berlin, or at one of the TechEd On The Road events in Louisville (USA), Bangalore (India) and Sydney (Australia), to find out more about our latest user experience innovations. I myself will be in Berlin and Bangalore, so feel free to approach me after my talks if you have any specific questions. Iâ€™m looking forward to meeting some of you!

 This blog posts gives an overview of all the UX related sessions at all four events:

  • Exciting UX talks at TechEd â€“ Virtual, or meet us in Berlin and On The Road (USA, India, Australia).

 Please continue using the community to share your learnings and best practices, either by posting articles yourselves or via comments on this post. You can also follow me in the community if you want to be notified about further similar updates from me.

entry.title: On-Premise Business AI Infrastructure for Small and Medium Enterprises Using NVIDIA DGX Spark
entry.content:
Disclaimer: this article is written without Generative AI, even for the proof reading ðŸ˜Š Enjoy the article written by human that is not common nowadays

Why Business AI?

That is what we always must start with. The business case should go first, for sure, and then we should evaluate possible deployment options, costs and security.

Statistics says that 95% of Generative AI implementations failed and that really scares the market in SAP enterprise software domain as well.

But letâ€™s be honest, we are trying to sell Business AI anywhere as technology, forgetting about the customers, their uniqueness and their current pain points.

At Skybuffer starting from February 2025 (during the last 9 months) we have talked to more than 250 customers of different sizes presenting them Business AI technologies and discussing their use cases, or better to say helping them to find how Business AI can help their employees and partners to automate companyâ€™s workflows.

There are three main groups of use cases, as we see it now:

  • Direct interaction with SAP backend system via corporate messengers that brings simplicity and mobility at the same time. In many cases Creating or Updating data in SAP from mobile phones or via Teams brings real value.
  • Converting any unstructured data to knowledge, like SharePoint sources, attachments in SAP, support tickets. Mixing those things together, in different document original languages create real value for employees providing them access to the data that is hidden in most of the organizations.
  • Capacity heavy activities delivered by AI agents, especially helpful with emails data analysis, where the main data is always in attachments. Sometimes it requires to utilize OCR extracting data from scanned PDFs in those scenarios. Some excellent examples are processing vendors emails and posting invoice or service entry sheets into SAP or receiving emails from customers converting their external purchasing data to sales orders.

That is why SAP customers with any SAP backend system, either SAP ECC or S/4HANA, can implement Business AI today. I am not saying that it covers the entire Business AI implementation benefits, however, that is what we are focusing on now and helping SAP customers to allocate the benefits of using the technology.

Costs

In our opinion, Business AI is close to being the tool that must be deployed inside IT infrastructure, but a technology that is to being considered only if it returns the investment. Think about the indirect impact of missing Business AI in your business landscape. For example, consider the costs of hiring new staff because your employees are moving to other companies that utilize modern technologies. Why should they move? Obvious, because of the same reason we are all talking about Generative AI â€“ to stay competitive on the market.

However, costs of AI must be assessed carefully, because in most of the architecture approaches Business AI is a consumption-based solution. Risky, isnâ€™t it? Of course! Consumption is hard to estimate, and it is also hard to avoid picks, so budgets of Business AI productive usage might be unacceptably high compared to the potential savings the technology brings. That is why we built Skybuffer AI as a solution with the double deployment options:

  • On premise, there is a clear and 100% predictable TCO.
  • On SAP BTP, this is a great option for CPEA contracts, for example, because in this case Business AI consumes the credits that are already paid, and we avoid extra costs for the infrastructure.

Why is DGX Spark in the article name?

Well, DGX Spark here is not because it is a buzz word now, for sure. That is because DGX Spark provides an excellent opportunity for small and medium enterprises to bring 15x15x12 cm GPU-unit to support their Business AI operations for a very compatible price. Actually, it allows us to keep both compute-unit and GPU-unit in the network avoiding data leakage and consumption-based costs. Excellent? Of course!

Here is how we use it deploying Skybuffer AI on premise:

Figure 01. Skybuffer AI deployment with GPU-unit served by DGX Spark

Criticism?

Yes, even writing this article I am already hearing the criticism ðŸ˜Š Guessing the comments like, â€œthat is not for productive environmentâ€, â€œDGX Spark tokens generation too low to serve even Small businessesâ€ and many other sharp negatives. But letâ€™s move back to the beginning of the article and understand the reason why Iâ€™ve spent so much time talking about use cases first. Yes, now it is obvious that many mentioned use cases can be addressed by DGX Spark working as GPU-unit. Example? Easy!

Example #1: Vendor emails processing with data posting into SAP backend and saving originals (files) into the DMS (like SharePoint, Join, Google or whatever DMS is in use).

In the architecture mentioned above, Skybuffer AI allows almost out of the box creation of an AI Agent that will check, for example, Account Payable mailbox, read emails, analyze attachments, move them to DMS and create financial postings in SAP backend saving links to the attachments in DMS (either external or internal SAP DMS) on the SAP financial document level. In scenario, if we schedule the agent carefully, it can work in the almost synchronous 24/7 mode.

In case we schedule the Vendor Emails processing AI Agent with the limit to process just one vendor email in the minute, we will avoid pick system loads, and in this case, we can keep AI agent active 24/7. In such deployment it will be able to process 1 440 emails and create postings in SAP a day, that gives us 43 200 a month and amazing number of 518 400 documents a year!! All powered by one DGX Spark GPU-unit keeping the data on premise and avoiding cloud consumption.

That is what we call a proper deployment of Business AI. And Small and Medium businesses do not usually have such big number of documents from vendors, even the Cirque du Soleil does not have according to the latest SAP news post ðŸ˜Š What we usually do, we add extra Business AI scenarios to be processed by the same Skybuffer AI deployment.

Example #2: Automation of SAP user management services

Small and Medium businesses do use password-based login to SAP backend, so users keep locking themselves or forgetting their passwords. Do we need a powerful GPU-unit with the full size LLM to automate this? No, for sure. We can add those business scenarios to the AI Agent that is processing Vendor Emails ðŸ˜Š

Example #3: Bank data reconciliation

The same setup can be used to assist financial department to match bank transactions to the billing documents in SAP and post accruals for the cases that could not be reconciled, for example, those that miss billing data in SAP that is not created just because someone has forgotten to enter it or integration interfaces have data processing issues. DGX Spark GPU-unit provides particularly good enough capacity here as well.

Those are just a few examples that wind away the skepticism about the utilization of DGX Spark in productive environment.

Is it safe to invest in the on-premise Business AI setup?

If you need full control over costs and data security, the answer is yes. And we think that the answer is yes in general, because Skybuffer AI dual deployment capabilities gives companies the guarantee that on premise Business AI investment can follow their potential future cloud strategy. I am writing and hearing again â€œwhat is this crazy man talking about! On premise investment can follow cloud strategies?? That is a paradox!â€. And again, the answer is No, of course there is no paradox! If we look at the deployment of Skybuffer AI with integration with SAP Joule:

 Figure 02: Skybuffer AI deployment in SAP BTP with integration with SAP Joule

That is what we call real flexibility!

Sounds like a Gap Closing Solution?

Yes, that is the conclusion we have. There no hard choice anymore to run Business AI on premise or on SAP BTP, no prerequisites to start using Business AI, because the deployment in this article works with SAP ECC (down to 7.01 and even below), SAP S/4HANA on premise or SAP S/4HANA in private cloud. The only question must be asked, when we are talking about Business AI, is about the scenario the company should start with? Youâ€™ve seen in our examples that Business AI deployments might bring benefits working in the scenarios that are independent from the historical data you have in your SAP backend and the historical data quality (sometimes it is called data silos), or scenarios that are independent from the version of your system and the point in time of your current digital journey. No need to wait for the upgrades, migrations, or other activities that sound like an act of catching a tail ðŸ˜Š. Just allocate some budget for Business AI deployment, for example, on-premise deployment on DGX Spark that is very affordable, and get the positive feedback from your employees or business partners and enjoy your business workflows simplifications.

entry.title: Install custom functions in COHV (3/3)
entry.content:
Introduction

The previous two episodes have demonstrated how to create and register a custom mass processing function code in COHV as well as have provided an outline of the actual implementation of the mass processing. However, the implementation has not done anything useful, yet.

Now, it is the time to add some meat to the implementation and dive into more advanced topics like test mode, function parametrization and order updates.

 

Test mode

Let us start with test mode. Typically, SAP standard mass processing functions provide a test mode option that runs all data processing without actually saving any changes or updates. That is particularly useful if you want to test a mass processing run without committing the updates.
Figure 1 Test mode on

Figure 2 Test mode off

The implementation of the mass processing function does not need to explicitly handle test mode operation, i.e. either to rollback or commit changes. That is done by COHV backbone. Make sure to test thoroughly if the test mode is used to make sure that the custom mass processing function is compatible with the test mode handling in COHV. If you are not sure, the rule of thumb is not to use the test mode.

 

Passing parameters to the mass processing function

Mass processing functions can be supplied with additional parameters. That is often used in SAP standard functions, and it can be enabled for custom ones.

First, additional parameters need to be added to the transparent table and the dialog structure that have been created in the episode 2. Make sure to add the same fields of the same type to the table and to the structure.
Figure 3 The transparent table with a parameter

Figure 4 The dialog structure with a parameter

Once that is done, the parameter will appear in COHV.
Figure 6 The function's parameter in COHV

 

Mass processing logic implementation

Now, letâ€™s implement the mass processing logic to update production orders. My goal is to change production orders quantity by the value passed with the function parameter. The implementation goes into Z_CO_WORK999_EXEX_SINGLE function. Refer to the previous episode for the details of the function creation.
Figure 7 A snippet of the mass processing logic implementation

Here is the entire implementation of the custom mass processing logic, which consists of the following steps:

  1. Get a production order number from LS_COWBPAR-OBJNR
  2. Read the orderâ€™s header details with the BAPI_PRODORD_GET_DETAIL function
  3. Modify the order quantity by the value of the function parameter. It is available in the LS_COWBPAR-QTYCHANGE field
  4. Update the order with the BAPI_PRODORD_CHANGE function
*** BEGIN custom mass processing logic
   DATA:
     prodord    TYPE cowrk_s_prodord_mask,
     return     TYPE bapiret2,
     headers    TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF bapi_order_header1,
     orderdata  TYPE bapi_pp_order_change,
     orderdatax TYPE bapi_pp_order_changex,
     dummy      TYPE string.
 
  prodord = ls_cowbpar-objnr.
 
  CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_PRODORD_GET_DETAIL'
     EXPORTING
       number        = prodord-aufnr
       order_objects = VALUE bapi_pp_order_objects( header = abap_true )
     TABLES
       header        = headers.
 
  READ TABLE headers INDEX 1 ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<header>).
   orderdata-quantity = <header>-target_quantity + ls_cowbpar-qtychange.
   orderdatax-quantity = abap_true.
 
  CLEAR return.
 
  CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_PRODORD_CHANGE'
     EXPORTING
       number     = prodord-aufnr
       orderdata  = orderdata
       orderdatax = orderdatax
     IMPORTING
       return     = return.
 
  IF return IS INITIAL.
     MESSAGE s100(co) WITH prodord-aufnr INTO dummy.
   ELSE.
     MESSAGE ID return-id TYPE return-type NUMBER return-number
     WITH return-message_v1 return-message_v2 return-message_v3 return-message_v4
     INTO dummy.
   ENDIF.
 
  ls_context-aufnr = ls_exec_obj-aufnr.
   CALL FUNCTION 'CO_APPLLOG_WRITE_SYMSG'
     EXPORTING
       i_loghandle           = ls_appllog-log_handle
       i_syst                = syst
       is_context            = ls_context
     EXCEPTIONS
       application_log_error = 1
       OTHERS                = 2.
 *** END custom mass processing logic

entry.title: ðŸš€ Whatâ€™s New in Floorplan Manager (FPM) for Web Dynpro ABAP in SAP S/4HANA 2025
entry.content:
Dear SAP Community,

When it comes to the design of web-based user interfaces, SAP truly has a rich history. A great example is the EPM Purchase Order Demo (FPM/WDA application S_EPM_FPM_PO) (see Figure 1):

Figure 1: Application S_EPM_FPM_PO â€“ Design evolution over the years

Design themes such as Tradeshow, Corbusier, Blue Crystal, Belize, or Quartz are well known to many developers. But the journey doesnâ€™t end there â€” it continues toward new Horizons and compliance with the WCAG 2.2 Accessibility Standard.

In the latest releases, several new features have been added to the Floorplan Manager (FPM) / Web Dynpro ABAP framework, driven by customer feedback, SAP design standards, and general product evolution. With the ABAP Platform 2025 and SAP S/4HANA 2025 (on-premise, private cloud, and public cloud editions), we are delivering several enhancements that can be activated easily â€” either automatically through delivery or manually with minimal configuration or coding effort.

ðŸ§­ Page Header UIBBs & Object Page Mode

In one of my previous blogs on S/4HANA 2023, ðŸ‘‰ Team FPM: How to Render an FPM Overview Page to Look Like a SAP Fiori Object Page, I introduced the Object Page Mode for the Overview Page (OVP) floorplan.

This mode allows you to render an FPM Overview Page application like a Fiori Object Page. Combined with a Page Header UIBB, you get a dynamic object header that automatically expands and collapses while scrolling. You can also pin the header to keep it fixed. You can easily try this out in the Search Page of the EPM Purchase Order Demo (see Figure 2).

Figure 2: S_EPM_FPM_PO with Page Header, Pin and List Item Navigation

The new List-Item Navigation lets users navigate to a Purchase Orderâ€™s detail page in a Fiori-compliant way. On the detail page, the Object Page Mode provides faster and more precise scrolling to specific screen areas (sections or UIBBs) using the Navigation Bar (see Figure 3).

Figure 3: Purchase Order Detail Page with Anchor Bar

Configuration

  • Object Page Mode is activated in the General Settings as a Floorplan Mode (see Figure 4).
  • To use a dynamic object header, define a Page Header Area in the layout and add Page Header UIBBs.

Figure 4: Object Page Mode setting in FLUID for OVP Floorplan S_EPM_UX_PO_OVP

In the List or Tree UIBB, a List-Item Navigation corresponds to rendering a Link-To-Action column differently. You can achieve this by checking Render as Navigation Column in the column configuration (see Figure 5).

Figure 5: Setting â€œPurchase Order IDâ€ as Navigation Column in FLUID for List UIBB EPM_PO_OVP_SEARCH_LIST_CFG

Additional Remarks

Some OVP floorplan features may behave differently in Object Page Mode. This can affect:

  • UIBB Selector and Page Master splitter control
  • Section and UIBB stacking
  • Personalization and panel behavior

However, Power User Modes allow overriding some restrictions â€” such as expanding and collapsing panels, or rearranging the layout by using the personalization dialog.

ðŸ§© CSS Grid Layout & WCAG 2.2 Compliance

Another major improvement is the WCAG 2.2-compliant rendering of forms. Weâ€™ve significantly enhanced the responsiveness of the Form/Repeater UIBB (GL2) by adopting a CSS Grid Layout.

This ensures that forms remain usable and readable â€” even at screen widths as low as 320px (mobile phone format) â€” without horizontal scrolling (see Figure 6).

 Figure 6: â€œPurchase Order Detailsâ€ form in different screen sizes

In the configuration editor (FLUID), you can enable the CSS Grid layout at General Settings â†’ Layout Design Type â†’ Responsive (see Figure 7).

Figure 7: FLUID configuration for Form UIBB EPM_PO_OVP_HEADER_FORM_CFG

ðŸ’¬Message Toasts & Invisible Alerts

In this context, itâ€™s worth mentioning the Message Toast and Invisible Alert features, which enhance both usability and accessibility. A Message Toast is a small, non-disruptive popup for success messages that disappears automatically after a few seconds (see Figure 8). The  IF_FPM_MESSAGE_MANAGER ABAP interface now provides the REPORT_MESSAGE_TOAST method for this purpose. You can also enable a Toast Mode globally with the SET_TOAST_MODE( IV_TOAST_MODE = GC_TOAST_MODE-ENABLED ) method,  ensuring that messages of severity Success (S) are displayed as toasts by default (see also SAP Help Portal).

Figure 8: â€œData Savedâ€ Toast in S_EPM_FPM_PO

An Invisible Alert, on the other hand, is used to inform screen reader users about content changes that are visible but not triggered by them â€” ensuring WCAG 2.2 compliance. Use the REPORT_INVISIBLE_ALERT method from the IF_FPM_MESSAGE_MANAGER interface for this purpose.

ðŸ”™FLP Back Navigation

Finally, let us introduce Back Navigation in the SAP Fiori Launchpad (FLP).

With SAP S/4HANA 2025, the Floorplan Manager for Web Dynpro ABAP continues its evolution toward:
