entry.title: Secure By Default: SAP S/4HANA 2025 â€“ The Security Journey Continues
entry.content:
What began as a bold initiative to strengthen the default security posture of SAP S/4HANA has, over the years, evolved into a core principle of the product. While the journey from concept to execution took time, weâ€™ve now reached a point where Secure By Default is not just an aspiration - itâ€™s a continuously expanding reality. With each release, more robust security settings are seamlessly integrated, helping customers benefit from enhanced protection without additional effort.

With the release of SAP S/4HANA 2025, also named SAP Cloud ERP Private 2025,  another step was taken by SAP S/4HANA supported by ABAP Platform to cover some additional topics for new installations, conversions, and system copies.

Identical to the former years, Secure By Default settings are applied for

    • SAP S/4HANA 2025 / SAP Cloud ERP Private 2025
    • All SAP products based on S/4HANA Foundation 2025

List of new Secure By Default Settings

In new installations, system copies, and conversions the following security relevant settings and configurations are applied automatically:

    • Add support for TLS1.3 for web-based interfaces of SAP S/4HANA in addition to TLS1.2
    • Adjust the security log of ICM to make it machine-readable for easier integration into SIEM solutions
    • Disable support for SAP logon tickets while still accepting SAP Assertion Tickets
    • Configure a Report-only Content Security Policy (CSP) for faster introduction of a Content Security Policy as second level of defence for S/4HANA
    • Disable the outdated ICM content scan interface as dedicated checks have been introduced in browser-based applications against Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and input validation.

Additional Information

As with SAP S/4HANA 1909, SAP S/4HANA 2020, SAP S/4HANA 2021, SAP S/4HANA 2023 customers will receive the security settings automatically with new installations, system copies and conversions. An opt-out is possible for the security relevant profile parameters but not recommended from SAP side. More details can be found in SAP Note 2926224.

As Secure By Default settings cannot and will not cover all aspects of security settings in S/4HANA systems, we highly recommend customers to perform additional reviews and improvements of their security settings. Good sources are the SAP security whitepapers. Secure by Default settings provide a good starting point, but there are additional security settings and configurations which are either customer specific, cannot be shipped as default or need to be applied on a regular basis (e.g., security patching).

    • Use the SAP-provided tools and services, such as Early Watch Alert, Configuration Validation and System Recommendations in order to display missing security patches. These inform you about gaps in a cost-efficient way.
    • Always introduce disruptive security settings with good timing. Conversion projects and new installations are opportunities to increase security. As a benefit, security testing can be included as part of the testing activities planned within the project. This leverages synergies in the area that has proven to be particularly costly.

Please refer to these blog posts for older SAP S/4HANA releases

    • For SAP S/4HANA 2023 â€“ Secure By Default, please also refer to this blog https://blogs.sap.com/2023/10/18/another-chapter-of-secure-by-default-for-sap-s-4hana-2023/
    • For SAP S/4HANA 2022 â€“ Secure By Default, please also refer to this blog https://blogs.sap.com/2022/11/03/secure-by-default-returns-with-sap-s-4hana-2022
    • For SAP S/4HANA 2021 â€“ Secure By Default, please also refer to this blog The story resumes â€“ Secure By Default for SAP S/4HANA 2021
    • For SAP S/4HANA 2020 â€“ Secure By Default, please also refer to this blog Secure By Default for SAP S/4HANA 2020
    • For SAP S/4HANA 1909 â€“ Secure By Default, please also refer to this blog Secure By Default: Ways To Harden Your Systems At (Almost) No Cost

Complete List of all SAP S/4HANA Secure By Default Settings

Below you can find a complete list of all Secure By Default settings that are included in SAP S/4HANA 2025. Bold entries were added with SAP S/4HANA 2025:

    • Security relevant profile parameters are set to secure values which increases security in areas such as:
        • Mandatory SSL Protection of session logon tickets (part of S/4HANA 2022)
        • Disable support for SAP logon tickets while still accepting SAP Assertion Tickets (part of S/4HANA 2025)
        • Protect the RFC gateway against unauthorized RFC call forwarding (part of S/4HANA 2022)
        • Strong password policies and password hashes (part of S/4HANA 2020)
        • Protection of internal system communication (part of S/4HANA 2020)
        • Strengthened authorizations system (part of S/4HANA 1909)
        • Enhanced RFC interface protection (part of S/4HANA 1909)
        • Enforce TLS1.2-only for web-based interfaces of SAP S/4HANA covering SAP Internet Communication Manager (ICM), SAP Start Service, SAP Host Agent (part of S/4HANA 2022)
        • Add support for TLS1.3 for web-based interfaces of SAP S/4HANA in addition to TLS1.2 (part of S/4HANA 2025)
        • Disable the old insecure tickets for trusted / trusting communication (part of S/4HANA 2023)
        • Disable the outdated ICM content scan interface as dedicated checks have been introduced in the browser-based applications against Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and input validation (part of S/4HANA 2025)
    • Security relevant configurations and customizing are set to secure values
        • Prevent usage of non-reference user as reference user (part of S/4HANA 2022)
        • 3 parameters were changed to secure defaults in the Transport Management (part of S/4HANA 2021)
        • Web protection is increased by activation of the UCON HTTP allowlist (part of S/4HANA 2021)
        • Start authorizations for WebDynpro were enabled for an improved security for Webdynpro applications (part of S/4HANA 2021)
        • All available scenarios of the Switchable Authorization Framework (SACF) are activated which adds additional functional authorization checks for technical function modules (part of S/4HANA 2020)
        • All available scenarios of the Generic Application Access Rules (SLDW) were activated as defined by SAP development (part of S/4HANA 2021)
        • Prevent the assignment of users to roles as part of transports to avoid that users get authorizations in higher tiers while importing transports (part of S/4HANA 2023)
    • Security relevant logging was enabled to support traceability and security monitoring
        • Performance, usability and analysis optimized log of RFC and SICF usage to support deactivation of unused RFC function modules and SICF services (part of S/4HANA 2022 and S/4HANA 2023)
        • Security Audit Log is activated what allows customers to trace critical activities in the system (part of S/4HANA 1909)
        • Activation of table logging for business-critical tables (part of S/4HANA 2021)
        • HTTP server and HTTP client log of the SAP Internet Communication Manager is enabled (part of S/4HANA 1909)
        • Granular logging of Secure By Default activations in application log for easier debugging in conversions (part of S/4HANA 2023)
        • Adjust the security log of ICM to make it machine-readable for easier integration into SIEM solutions (part of S/4HANA 2025)
        • Configure a Report-only Content Security Policy (CSP) for faster introduction of a Content Security Policy as second level of defence for S/4HANA (part of S/4HANA 2025)
    • HANA for S/4HANA relevant configurations were enabled to improve traceability and encryption
        • SAP HANA Audit Log is switched on for HANAs running SAP S/4HANA. This enables traceability of activities on SAP HANA database level (part of S/4HANA 2021)
        • Leverage the automated activation of HANA Data at Rest Encryption Features as part of HANA2 SP07 installations to ensure that business data cannot be accessed on file system level (part of S/4HANA 2023)
    • Values of additional security relevant profile parameters were changed in the kernel default

entry.title: Supply Protection and Other Methods in aATP
entry.content:
In advanced Available-to-Promise (aATP), customers have different options to optimize the availability of articles or products. Supply protection (SUP) is one of these methods, which is integrated into other processes in aATP. 
Sometimes itâ€™s not clear how supply protection works with other methods and how to differentiate to other methods. The methods have a lot in common, like the usage of a characteristics catalog. But there are also differences regarding the use cases, the usage in a process, and there are pros and cons for every method. 

Letâ€™s look at different aspects of the integration of supply protection into the following processes in aATP: 

  • Product Availability Check (PAC) 
  • Product Allocation (PAL) 
  • Backorder Processing (BOP) 
  • Alternative-Based Confirmation (ABC) 
  • Supply Assignment (aRUN) 

Link:

SAP Help: Integration into other Processes

Supply Protection and Product Availability Check (PAC) 

Planned supply protection is relevant for the product availability check (PAC), which determines whether a demand (for example, from a sales order) can be confirmed. The product availability check compares the request of the sales order with the available stock for the related material. Within this logic, there is also a check if there is supply protection available for the relevant combination of material and planning level. If yes, the system calculates the restricted quantities and reduces the available stock for the sales document. If this reduced quantity is not sufficient to meet the request, the sales document will not be (fully) confirmed for the requested delivery date. Supply protection also reduces the available stock after the replenishment lead time (RLT). However, the availability check is calculated with infinity stock. The restrictions defined by supply protection donâ€™t have an impact after the RLT.  

Whether supply protection is considered in the product availability check depends on the settings for the scope of the availability check. Only if supply protection is activated in the scope of check for the related checking rule, will PAC consider supply protection. For more information, see â€¯How to Activate Supply Protection. 

As supply protection is integrated in the basic method of the product availability check, the impact of supply protection when creating a sales document is also shown in theâ€¯Review Availability Check Resultâ€¯app, as part of the intermediate results of the check. For more information, see â€¯Supply Protection in Review Availability Check Result. 

The following illustration shows how supply protection reduces the availability by adding virtual demands:

Supply Protection within the Product Availability Check

Supply Protection and Product Allocation (PAL) 

Several use cases can be addressed with product allocation or with supply protection; and sometimes they can even be used in combination. Logically, the product allocation check is performed before the availability is checked. Therefore, PAL can limit the request which is checked in PAC (together with SUP). 

What are the differences between Product Allocation and Supply Protection? 

With the sales product allocation check, it is possible to define an upper limit for a group. A matching demand canâ€™t get a higher confirmation compared to the limit defined in product allocation. As the sales PAL is checked in advance of the product availability check, the allocation ignores the availability situation. A demand which is limited by PAC canâ€™t get more quantity, even if there is no shortage. In case of a shortage situation, a demand within the defined allocation can get the quantities if the stock is available, and if the PAL limit isnâ€™t exceeded. This leads to the issue that another requested quantity canâ€™t get confirmation although there is a matching PAL quantity. 

Supply Protection and Product Allocation
Supply protection is integrated in the product availability check and considers the availability situation. It adds virtual demands so that the availability is reduced, depending on whether the demand matches a supply protection object or not. If there is a lot of supply compared to the protected quantities, supply protection doesnâ€™t have an impact on sales. 

Can Supply Protection and Product Allocation be Used as Complementary Methods? 

Yes, with supply protection, minimum quantities can be defined. With this, it can be ensured that even in shortage situations important groups can get some quantities. With product allocation, limits can be defined, which prevent a group from taking too much quantity and not leaving enough for others. 

However, there is a risk of a wrong setup, where product allocation prevents the consumption of quantities protected by supply protection, and vice versa. This is the case when, for example, supply protection with high priority exists for a key customer, and thereâ€™s also a product allocation object matching the demands of this key customer. If the product allocation is already consumed, this customer canâ€™t order more quantity. In this case, consumption of protected quantities in supply protection isnâ€™t possible, and other demands are restricted by this. 

Advantages of Supply Protection 
Allows different settings of restrictions, but will not limit demands, if there is enough stock/supply. 

Advantages of Product Allocation 
Can be set up also on more generic levels (not only a specific material-plant combination), which requires less maintenance. 

Link: 

SAP Help: Best Practices for Supply Protection â€“ Using Supply Protection and Product Allocation 

Supply Protection and Backorder Processing (BOP) 

With backorder processing, it is possible to recheck orders with specific rules so that orders which have been confirmed may lose their confirmation while others can now get confirmed. With BOP, itâ€™s possible to reallocate available stock to competing sales orders, allowing customers to prioritize some orders ("winners") over others ("losers"). 

This seems to be close to the idea of supply protection. However, the logic of BOP is to reopen sales documents and change the sequence. A winner is processed first and has a rule to get a better result. A loser will come later and has a rule that the result can be worse. 

Links:  

SAP Help: Backorder Processing (CA-ATP-BOP) 

How does Supply Protection work together with BOP? 

While processing backorders, supply protection is checked as well. The consumption of protected quantities in supply protection will get removed temporarily, and the orders which are processed first are also checked against supply protection. The result will be different, but it considers the restrictions of supply protection. 

Naturally, it wouldnâ€™t make sense to set up protection groups with high priority for demands which should be â€œlosersâ€, according to the defined logic for BOP. 

Supply Protection and Alternative Base Confirmation (ABC) 

With ABC, it is possible to define alternative options for supply by exchanging a product and/or a plant. Depending on the rules for ABC, a demand for product A could be replaced by product B, which is not the same but treated as a good substitute. 

From the perspective of supply protection, this is always a new, independent check. The reason is quite simple: product and plant are keys for supply protection. If a product is exchanged by another product, the check for supply protection will search for matches and calculate restrictions for a different material-plant-combination. 

In this case, there wonâ€™t be a consumption for the originally matching supply protection object. For the second check, consumption might be written. 

Link: 

SAP Help: Alternative Base Confirmation (CA-ATP-ABC) 

Supply Protection and Supply Assignment (ARun) 

Supply assignment ensures that the supply is assigned to the orders according to the changing requirements. Supply protection is only a virtual demand and doesnâ€™t have a direct relationship to supply elements. Quantities which are assigned via supply assignment are not considered as available quantities in PAC. Settings in supply assignment can be used to respect or overrule restrictions defined by Supply Protection. 

Links: 

  • Community Blog: Supply Protection in Supply Assignment(ARun) 
  • SAP Help: Supply Protection in Supply Assignment 

Related Links: 

  • SAP Community Blog: Supply Protection in a Nutshell  
  • FAQ-Document: 3141787 - FAQ - Supply Protection (SUP) with advanced ATP

entry.title: Clean Core Extensibility: Balancing Standardization and Differentiation
entry.content:
Unlock Agility and Stability with a Clean Core

In todayâ€™s fast-paced digital landscape, organizations need both agility to innovate and stability to grow sustainably. The key to balancing these goals is a clean digital core â€” an ERP foundation that stays standardized, upgrade-stable, and ready for innovation.
But keeping your core clean doesnâ€™t mean giving up differentiation. It means being deliberate â€” extending only where it creates true business value and competitive advantage.
This is the essence of Clean Core Extensibility.

Clean Core Extensibility: Balancing Standardization and Differentiation

The SAP Business Suite brings this vision to life by unifying ERP and line-of-business applications on a common data foundation with embedded AI and SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) for extensibility. Together, these capabilities enable organizations to connect and optimize every function across the enterprise, ensuring that innovation remains upgrade-stable and grounded in reliable, trusted data.

SAPâ€™s clean core strategy is built on five guiding principles â€” Processes, Extensibility, Data, Integrations, and Operations. In this blog, we focus on the Extensibility principle, exploring how organizations can innovate safely and strategically while maintaining a standardized, upgrade-stable foundation.

The five guiding principles of a clean core

1. Why You Need a Clean Core â€“ and the New Extensibility Model

A clean core is the foundation of a modern cloud ERP strategy. It runs on standardized, upgrade-friendly configurations that minimize technical debt and maximize agility.

A clean core ensures:

  • Faster innovation through seamless cloud updates
  • Lower TCO and reduced complexity
  • Business agility through modular, composable extensions

While the clean core provides stability, extensibility defines how you tailor the system to your needs â€” without losing upgradeability. To enable innovation without sacrificing stability, SAP introduced an evolved Extensibility Model â€” separating standard ERP capabilities from custom innovations.

This cloud-first, modular approach allows extensions to live outside the core while connecting seamlessly to it.
It enables organizations to:

  • Build innovations safely on SAP BTP
  • Adopt continuous updates without disruption
  • Keep systems clean, stable, and flexible

The goal is simple: empower business differentiation while maintaining standardization at the core.

2. Strategic Extensibility in Practice: Extending and Applying the Model

Not all extensions add value â€” and not all differentiation requires custom code. True extensibility is strategic: focus on what drives growth, efficiency, or customer experience. Adopt best practices for core business processes, and customize only when it creates measurable advantage.

SAPâ€™s evolved Extensibility Model emphasizes decoupling extensions from the standard. By leveraging SAP Build, organizations can implement both on-stack (ABAP Cloud) and side-by-side (BTP) extensions, enabling key users and developers to innovate without modifying the SAP core. This approach ensures easier upgrades, better maintainability, and preserves upgrade stability.

Follow SAPâ€™s extensibility levels to maintain a clean core:

  1. Adopt a BTP-first mindset â€“ Use SAP Build on SAP BTP for custom logic, integrations, and innovation.
  2. Prefer Level A/B extensions: Level A - on-stack or side-by-side via released APIs, Level B - Making use of Classic APIs
  3. Use Level C (utilization of SAP-internal objects) only when absolutely necessary and apply the changelog.
  4. Avoid Level D and continuously refactor legacy code â€“ Move unused extensions out of the core.

This structured approach helps organizations balance standardization and differentiation, ensuring a clean core that is robust, adaptable, and ready for innovation.

Guidance for SAPâ€™s extensibility levels

3. Measuring Your Clean Core with RISE with SAP Methodology: The Clean Core Measurement Framework

Maintaining a clean core is an ongoing process. The Clean Core Measurement Framework helps organizations assess their governance and maturity, define target actions, and track progress through clean core KPIs.

The Governance and Maturity assessment evaluates the tooling, governance, and know-how required to get and stay clean. It calculates a current score for each clean core dimension and can be performed at any stage â€” before, during, or after transformation. Based on this, customers can define a target score aligned with their strategic goals. These criteria and assessments are fully embedded in the RISE with SAP Methodology.

Clean core KPIs complement this by measuring adherence during both implementation and operations. Derived from system data, these KPIs provide automated, transparent insights â€” fully visible in the RISE with SAP Methodology Dashboard.

Together, these measurements create visibility and accountability â€” helping organizations stay on track toward a truly clean core.

 4. How to Get Started

Begin your journey toward a Clean Core with Extensibility by reading our White Paper: Clean core extensibility White paper
It outlines a six-step path to achieving a clean core â€” from defining your strategy and analyzing custom code to adopting extension guidelines, establishing governance, and building upgrade-safe extensions.

And donâ€™t miss the video Achieving Clean Core with the Updated Clean Core Extensibility White Paper for an expert walkthrough of the key concepts and updates.

Start today â€” and turn your clean core into a foundation for continuous innovation.

 5. Customer Example: CAP Group â€“ Growth Through Clean Core

CAP Group modernized its ERP by moving custom logic to SAP BTP, achieving:

  • Simplified upgrades and operations
  • Faster innovation delivery
  • Improved scalability and flexibility

Their success shows that a clean core enables innovation and control to coexist â€” driving growth with less complexity. For more details, explore the CAP Group Clean Core Story on SAP.com.

Conclusion

A clean core isnâ€™t about avoiding customization â€” itâ€™s about making it count.
By standardizing your foundation, extending only where it drives advantage, and continuously measuring your progress, you build an ERP thatâ€™s agile, efficient, and future-ready.

Balance standardization for efficiency with extensibility for differentiation â€” thatâ€™s the essence of a clean core.

entry.title: Oversized Requirements? Here's how to fix them.
entry.content:
Getting requirement sizing right is an important but less obvious driver of predictable SAP project delivery. It is the art of making requirements neither too big nor too small. This may sound like a detail, but it shapes everything that follows: how releases are planned, how work is owned, and how testing stays traceable. After formulation and classification standards, it is another dimension to properly creating requirements.

Why requirements granularity is important?

Granularity defines how big or small a requirement should be so that it can be delivered, tested, and accepted within a single delivery or release cycle.

On one hand, if requirements are too large, their delivery will stretch across waves. This means that one requirement will not be fully completed and fully tested within one Wave release. That breaks the flow of delivery and the traceability of results.

On the other hand, if requirements are too small, the requirements backlog swells with too many tiny items which adds administration effort and slows down the work.

The golden rule

SAP Activate recommends sizing requirements so they can be fully delivered and tested within a single Wave and inside one Work Package. This makes tracking progress from requirement through configuration to test case much easier.

To keep delivery predictable, adopt a simple rule: One Requirement â†’ One Work Package â†’ One Test Case â†’ One Wave

 Decomposition and Grouping

Use early Explore workshops for iterative refinement which is continuously splitting or regrouping requirements as delivery planning evolves.

If a requirement is too large, decompose it into smaller, independent, testable sub-requirements. Each should deliver a clear, standalone piece of value that can be tested independently. They still can be associated with each other in the same test plan.

If a requirement is too small, group it with other closely related requirements and reformulate them into one coherent requirement delivered as one work package.

The effort pays off: proper sizing makes ownership clear, simpler planning, and complete test traceability from requirement to configuration and testing results.

Iterative refinement

Skipping granularity refinement often leaves oversized requirements that may span two waves. This reduces transparency, complicates test coverage, and makes progress reporting unreliable. Right-sized requirements make governance measurable: every item in the backlog has a clear boundary, a single owner, and a defined success criteria.

Iterative refinement

Skipping granularity refinement often leaves oversized requirements that may span two waves. This reduces transparency, complicates test coverage, and makes progress reporting unreliable. Right-sized requirements make governance measurable: every item in the backlog has a clear boundary, a single owner, and a defined success criteria.

Jira practice

Granularity can be managed directly in Jira by defining clear parentâ€“child relationships between Requirements and their Deliverables. This approach keeps ownership, scheduling, and testing transparent.

  • Create each main Requirement as a standard level work item

  • In case of need for a decomposition, add sub-task level work items called Sub-Requirements underneath.

  • Map each Requirement or Sub-Requirement to a single Work Package that will be scheduled in one Wave to preserve traceability.

  • Link every requirement to the corresponding Jira Xray Test Cases that verify acceptance and completion.

 You can visualize the hierarchy using a Jira app such as Structure, to display dependencies and delivery scope clearly

 Whatâ€™s in it for you?

Requirements granularity may sound like a technical detail, but in SAP projects itâ€™s one of the strongest predictors of delivery stability. In simple terms, your project scheduling will be much more reliable.

So, next time before you approve a requirement in your backlog, ask: "Will this fit into one Wave, in one Work Package, tested by one Test Case?" If yes, go to the next requirement.

entry.title: SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA â€“ Replacing SAP Fiori apps during system conversion
entry.content:
SAP Fiori is the primary user experience of SAP S/4HANA.

So if you are already using SAP Fiori in the classic SAP Business Suite, the degree of change in SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA can come as a surprise. The uplift in SAP Fiori can add an extra unexpected challenge to your system conversion.  In this post you will learn which decisions are needed and gain some suggestions on how to resolve them.

Hint: The classic SAP Business Suite includes SAP ECC, SAP Suite on HANA, SAP Simple Finance, SAP SRM, SAP GRC, and other solutions running on SAP NetWeaver.

These suggestions are collated from experiences of myself and my colleagues in the Early Adopter Care program for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, and our SAP Customer Services & Delivery colleagues.

From our experiences across system conversion customers worldwide who are already using SAP Fiori in classic SAP Business Suite. These customers usually:

  •  Have deployed a limited number of SAP Fiori apps - usually less than 100 apps - in their classic SAP Business Suite environment. 
  • May be using SAP Fiori in a hybrid mode. For example, using SAP Fiori for employee self-service and manager self-service apps, and some targeted mobile apps, while SAP GUI is used for daily on-system tasks.
  • Want to take bring quick wins (aka immediate ROI) from the new/improved SAP Fiori launchpad features, and from the huge amount of predefined launchpad content available in SAP S/4HANA. 
  • Even where the strategy is to move all users to the central launchpad â€“ i.e. SAP Fiori launchpad in SAP Build Work Zone â€“ you still need your local launchpad â€“ i.e. SAP Fiori launchpad available on-stack in SAP S/4HANA â€“ deployed as well.  The local launchpad is the target for content federation, and gives you access on-stack configuration, administration apps, and clean core extension apps.  Refer to SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA â€“ Minimum UX you need for SAP Business AI and Clean Core.

First the good news: Your change management journey is easier. 

Even though the SAP Fiori launchpad has changed, your users will recognize:

  • the overall look and feel of the launchpad,
  • some of the main launchpad features such as Settings, Search, and Notifications
  • know generally how to work with tiles, links and apps.

Your target user experience: the SAP Fiori launchpad My Home page as it appears in SAP S/4HANA 2025.

Now for the work ahead!

Start by listing all your existing SAP Fiori apps, custom-built apps, partner-built apps, and any custom-built launchpad features.  A simple spreadsheet will do.

Hint: Do your best to capture the SAP Fiori app id for apps delivered by SAP.  You can use the app id to find successor apps.

When doing a system conversion to SAP S/4HANA:

  • You will need to decide which of your existing apps and launchpad features to retain, replace, or discard. 
  • You may need to adjust custom-built apps and custom-built launchpad features, such as launchpad plug-ins.
  • This includes partner-built apps and launchpad features that you are using.

In this blog post you will learn:

  • Replace your predefined SAP Fiori apps with successors
  • Retain your custom-built Fiori apps
  • Verify partner-built Fiori apps you have deployed
  • Review your launchpad feature usage for successors
  • Remember your administrators
  • Watchpoints when coming from SAP Fiori in Enterprise Portal
  • Reintroducing your upgraded launchpad to your business users
  • Learnings to get you started
  • Background information: Whatâ€™s behind the changes in SAP Fiori

Replace your predefined SAP Fiori apps with successors

Expect that most of the predefined SAP Fiori apps you are using in SAP Business Suite (SAP ECC) will need to be replaced.

Of the 836 SAP Fiori apps provided for the classic SAP Business Suite, only 248 of these are supported in SAP S/4HANA 2025. Thatâ€™s less than 30%. Of those 248 apps:

  • 3 apps are deprecated and should not be used
  • 20 apps are available with successor, so you should use the successor
  • 11 are reuse apps that provide sub-features and are not available as tiles
  • 27 are industry-specific (mostly IS-OIL and IS-HER) and not relevant to most customers
  • 69 are relevant only to SAP GRC
  • 12 are relevant to SAP HCM compatibility pack â€“ and are replaced by successors when moving to SAP HCM for SAP S/4HANA

Leaving only 106 apps generally available, or about 12% of apps.

Hint: You can test this for yourself in the SAP Fiori apps reference library, downloading your list of apps and running them through the Upgrade Impact Analysis against your target SAP S/4HANA release. Refer to SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA â€“ Upgrade Impact Analysis.

At most customers, the only app that is retained is SAP Fiori app F0862 My Inbox.

Hint: If you are currently using app F0862 My Inbox, you should consider with your system conversion:

  • Adding SAP Fiori app F6511 My Outbox to all users who have My Inbox.  My Outbox is a predefined app in SAP S/4HANA that reuses the same configuration as My Inbox. My Outbox provides self-service answers such as: Where is that workflow now? Who is the next approver? Is that workflow complete?
  • You may also want to consider adding the unified inbox across cloud solutions - SAP Task Center - which can be deployed with SAP Build Work Zone on desktop, and with SAP Mobile Start on mobile devices.

Most other apps will need to be replaced by successors.

 

General advice about successor apps

Sometimes there are obvious successors.

  • Successor apps can look and behave very differently to your current app. You will need to deploy the successor app to explore it.
  • Successor apps often have improved clean core compliant extension options. You will need to learn clean core techniques, such as Custom Fields, Custom Logic, and Adapt UI.
  • If you have extended your existing SAP Fiori app, you will need to review your extensions, decide if the extensions are still needed, and if needed, reapply them using clean core compliant techniques.

Sometimes there are no successors.

For example, where the functionality has been moved to a SAP Cloud solution.

Where there are no successors, you will need to consider your options, such as:

  • Deploy the successor SAP Cloud solution
  • Replace with a custom-built app
  • Revert to a classic UI â€“ such as SAP GUI, Web Dynpro application, or WebClient UI

Hint: If the classic UI works but is simply too busy for your users, or missing some defaults / tips, you can make some easy improvements with SAP Screen Personas. SAP Screen Personas is the Adapt UI for classic GUI transactions. There is no additional subscription needed for SAP Screen Personas. SAP Screen Personas flavors can be easily applied to existing launchpad content using the Launchpad App Manager â€“ Adaptation Mode to add the parameter for the Personas Flavor.

Refer to:

  • SAP Help â€“ SAP Screen Personas
  • How to use SAP Screen Personas with SAP Fiori Launchpad
  • SAP Fiori app F5740 Adapt UI for Classic Applications with Screen Personas

Example of Adapt UI for SAP GUI transactions in the SAP Fiori launchpad as it appears in SAP S/4HANA 2025 FPS0 : 

Adapt UI for GUI Transactions in SAP S/4HANA 2025 launches SAP Screen Personas flavor maintenance for the app

 

How to find Successor Apps

These are predictable patterns you can use:

  1. Review Related Apps in the SAP Fiori apps reference library
  2. Approve apps become My Inbox sub apps
  3. HCM apps move to SAP SuccessFactors and/or SAP HCM for SAP S/4HANA
  4. SRM apps move to Ariba or to Procurement
  5. Smart Business apps move from HANA Live to ABAP CDS Views
  6. Predictive Model apps move to Intelligent Scenario Lifecycle Management (ISLM)
  7. Factsheet apps move to SAP Fiori elements Object Page

 

1.   Review Related Apps in the SAP Fiori apps reference library

Check the Related Apps tab. In some cases, the successors apps are listed.

You may need check if there are already successor apps for the successors.

Hint: Use the most recent app for your SAP S/4HANA release.

If you are moving to SAP SuccessFactors, you should review alternatives in the relevant solution. For example, employee self-services apps in SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central.

You should also check for related options to unify the User Interface where you can. For example SAP Help â€“ SuccessFactors Employee Central Integration - Introduction to SAP Sâˆ•4HANA UI Integration with SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central

Hint: Some SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition customers who are planning their move to SAP SuccessFactors are taking a tactical approach to retain existing versions of SAP Fiori apps for HCM.  As an interim approach, they keep the Compatibility Pack for HCM to avoid the move to HCM for SAP S/4HANA.  

 

4.   SRM apps move to SAP Ariba, SAP Fieldglass or to Procurement

Start by reading this important reference blog post from SAP: SAP S/4HANA Procurement â€“ Considerations for customers with SAP SRM. This blog post gives an overview of the extended roadmap. 

If you are considering keeping a standalone SAP SRM in tandem with your SAP S/4HANA solution, you should also check the central SAP Note 2611066 - SAP SRM and S/4HANA for the latest information on the roadmap.

  • Support for actions
  • Support for long texts and attachments
  • Optional AI-assisted features, such as AI-assisted Smart Summarization***

For SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition, it is one of several AI features in planning to be made available with upcoming SAP S/4HANA 2025 feature pack stacks. Retain your custom-built apps

This is a tactical approach. Most custom-built apps based on SAP Fiori design and development models will convert relatively easily as classic SAP Fiori programming models are still supported in SAP S/4HANA. This includes custom-built sub-apps for tasks in SAP Fiori F0862 My Inbox.

Important: Supported means that the apps will technically still work. However, these classic techniques have several disadvantages compared to the latest techniques to support Enterprise-ready apps.  Refer to UI5 Demo Kit documentation -  Enterprise Features of SAPUI5.  Classic programming techniques usually require more effort to upgrade, are NOT considered Clean Core, and are NOT recommended for building new apps!

Refer to SAP Note 3578329 - Frameworks, Technologies and Development Patterns in Context of Clean Core Extensibility

You will need to review your custom-built apps for:

  • Frontend (SAPUI5) coding â€“ you will need to check for any adjustments needed due to the change in SAPUI5 version.  You should refer to the advice in UI5 Demo Kit â€“ Read Me First â€“ Upgrading .  You should consider verifying your apps using the SAPUI5 legacy-free version as explained in Explore SAPUI5/OpenUI5 1.136.x-legacy-free
  • Backend coding â€“ You will need to check if any database tables you update still exist, and if the OData V2 services you are using require any changes. These coding changes are typically covered by your custom code migration. 

Hint: In your SAP S/4HANA solution you can activate the on-stack Custom Code Migration apps to make cleaning your apps easier during/after system conversion:

  • F3191 Custom Code Migration

You need to prepare your business users for mandatory changes in your custom-built apps:

  • On system conversion, custom-built apps using the SAP Fiori elements floorplans are automatically upgraded to the latest version of the floorplan.
  • Usually this is a positive change as it makes it easier for your business users to adopt new apps in SAP S/4HANA â€“ especially Manage apps, Monitor apps, and Overview page app, and they get automatic benefits such as personsalization, Export, and Share features included with their apps.

 

If you decide to replace a custom-built or partner-built app that is currently coded as a SAPUI5 freestyle app, you should:

  • Update your programming practices to SAP Best Practices.
  • Consider moving custom-built apps to SAP Fiori elements for faster development and greater consistency for business users
  • Review the advanced extension options with the Flexible Programming Model Explorer â€“ these help you avoid creating a freestyle app â€¦ keeping your overall solution consistent
  • Consider applying SAPUI5 Flexibility Services â€“ to minimize future changes.

Explore the new SAPU5 legacy-free version to check the app against best practices

If you are intending to use SAP Build Work Zone, you may also want to consider whether you deploy your custom-built apps to the ABAP Platform of SAP S/4HANA, or to SAP BTP.  If your app uses any SAP BTP services, or integrates with non-SAP data or components, you should consider deploying to SAP BTP. 

 

Verify your partner-built apps and features

It is critical that you check with your partner whether your existing partner-built app or launchpad feature (e.g. launchpad plug-in) will also work for SAP S/4HANA.

Important: Do this early as it may impact your commercial arrangements with your partner.

If the apps and features are part of partner product you can refer to SAP Note 3634480 - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025 : Compatible Partner Products

Hint: For on-premise customers refer to SAP Note 3654390 - SAP S/4HANA, on-premise edition 2025: Compatible partner products

Where your partners were employed software developers who have custom-built apps for you, you may need them to review the front-end and back-end coding of their apps.

The same guidelines apply as for your self-developed custom-built apps.

 

Review your launchpad feature usage for successors

Many apps â€“ including custom-built apps â€“ rely on launchpad features to work. For a system conversion customer, the main features to review based on your existing usage are:

  • Themes
  • Navigation
  • Search
  • Notifications
  • User Settings
  • Custom-built launchpad plug-ins

You can speed up reviewing launchpad features by running a workshop with your business and technical stakeholders. 

The SAP Activate roadmaps for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition contain many UX Adoption accelerators, including the workshop template UX Adoption_ UX Strategy and Guiding Principles Workshop. This workshop template shows how to quickly present and capture Yes/No/Defer decisions on many launchpad features and common app features. 

There are several quick win features that you should consider including in your new launchpad configuration on SAP S/4HANA:

  • My Home for SAP S/4HANA â€“ This is a very attractive home page for business users. It already includes AI-assisted options in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition, which are planned to be made available to SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition (timing to be decided â€“ on current planning most likely a later FPS of SAP S/4HANA 2025 release). When using the central launchpad on SAP Build Work Zone, you can retain My Home for business users by using the federation option content exposure version 2.  Refer to: User Experience Advances with SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS01 (Private Cloud and On-Premise), SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA â€“ Pro-tips for demonstrating SAP Fiori â€“ Organizing your My Home page, and SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA - Simplifying My Home Activation from SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS02 or higher
  • Context-sensitive Help â€“ can be provided with SAP WalkMe digital adoption platform, or if you are an existing SAP EnableNow customer you can integrate with SAP EnableNow.
  • App Support â€“ self-service troubleshooting which captures error logs. This replaces transactions SU53 for identifying missing authorizations and so much more! Refer to blog post SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA â€“ New improvements in App Support
  • Manage News / Display News â€“ for news announcements. Next generation of transaction SM02. Refer to Empowering Business Users with Personalized News in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 Release Minimum release is SAP S/4HANA 2025 FPS0, minimum SAPUI5 version is 1.136.5.  You are recommended to patch up to the latest available SAPUI5 patch level.
  • MS Teams integration â€“ for collaboration and as a step towards working with Microsoft CoPilot. Refer to SAP Help - SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition - Integration - Integration with Microsoft Teams

 

Themes

If you applied custom themes you will need to rebuild them, as they will no longer be compatible with the SAPUI5 version of your target SAP S/4HANA release.  Refer to UI5 Demo Kit â€“ Read Me First - Supported Combinations of Themes and Libraries.

You should consider alternatives to avoid theme maintenance wherever possible.

For example, instead of using custom themes to highlight your Development or QAS environment, configure the System Information Bar.  This configured via Launchpad Configuration Parameters.

Refer to Learning  video Configuring the SAP Fiori Launchpad for SAP S/4HANA

You can also use Launchpad configuration parameters to:

  • Replace the logo
  • Set an alternative accessible text (tooltip) for the logo

If you do need to rebuild your themes, maximize your custom themes working life across future upgrades by making sure you rebuild on the latest SAP Theme family, which is currently Horizon (sap_horizon, sap_horizon_dark, sap_horizon_hcw, sap_horizon_hcd). 

You will need to use the tool UI Theme Designer â€“ which is provided as part of your SAP S/4HANA environment.  Within the UI Theme Designer, focus on using the Quick, Detailed, or Expert options.

Important: Avoid direct CSS changes. Across many project experiences, CSS changes to themes have the highest risk of introducing undesirable side-effects and have been known to break the standard behaviours of apps and features. For further advice, refer to UI5 Demo Kit â€“ Essentials â€“ Theming.

 

Navigation

Navigation around the launchpad moves from Groups to Spaces and Pages. Groups are deprecated. Spaces and pages bring:

  • Improved performance
  • Improved personalization â€“ on the page and on the My Home page
  • Better support for complex roles through merging of spaces, merging of pages, and automatic hiding of unauthorized tiles/spaces/pages
  • Easier change management â€“ as the space/page menu reinforces the major processes and activities of the role
  • Easier WYSIWYG layout maintenance through the SAP Fiori apps F4834 Manage Launchpad Spaces and F4512 Manage Launchpad Pages.

Hint: Spaces and pages also offer more site choices when using the central launchpad on SAP Build Work Zone.

A conversion to SAP S/4HANA is often the easiest time to move from Groups to Spaces and Pages, because you only have a few existing apps to move across.

A starter option is to migrate your current groups to pages using the tool Create Launchpad Pages from Groups (transaction /UI2/FLP_GTP).

Refer to:

  • SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA â€“ Migrating from groups to spaces and pages - Why, When, and Key Differences for Users
  • SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA â€“ How to migrate from groups to spaces and pages

Screenshot of the tool Create Launchpad Pages from Groups

 

Enterprise Search

More than 350 search models are provided.   

Classic index-based searches on the TREX or BWA are moved to the SAP HANA database. New searches based on CDS Views are added. You can use either all searches or only the CDS View based searches. In SAP S/4HANA 2025 there are now more CDS View-based search models than classic models.

Refer to SAP Help â€“ Enterprise Search â€“ Configuration Guide.

You can find all the search models via transactions ESH_DASHBOARD or ESH_COCKPIT.

You will want to deploy the SAP Fiori app (use predecessor app F3036 in releases SAP S/4HANA 2023 and below).  You can use this app to:

  • Review the status of CDS View search models.
  • Edit CDS View search models delivered by SAP
  • You can create your own custom search models based on CDS Views (SAP defined or custom-built in ADT).

Refer to:

  • SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA - How to find Enterprise Search connectors for SAP Fiori applications
  • SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA â€“Limit Search Object Access in Fiori Launchpad made easier

 

Notifications

Notifications are used far more widely in SAP S/4HANA that they were in SAP Business Suite. They extend across workflow, situations, process-specific notifications, smart business KPIs, and more.

  • Sending notifications by email is still possible but not encouraged.  
  • Notifications can be federated to the central launchpad in SAP Build Work Zone.
  • Push notifications are supported when using SAP Mobile Start (requires SAP Build Work Zone).

Refer to

  • SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA â€“ Which notification to use when â€“ Workflow, Situation Handling, KPIs, etc
  • SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA â€“ Which notification to use when â€“ Impact on Business Users
  • SAP Help â€“ ABAP Platform - SAP Fiori launchpad - User Guide â€“ Using the Launchpad - Working with Notifications.

Refer to:

  • SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA â€“ Which notification to use when â€“ Where and how to configure
  • SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA â€“ Which notification to use when â€“ Notifications for Admins and Developers

Notifications can be integrated to Microsoft Teams

  • SAP Help â€“ ABAP Platform â€“ SAP Fiori launchpad â€“ User Guide â€“ Working with Notifications Integrated into Microsoft Teams

 

User Settings

User Settings have improved with each release.   

Default Values are effectively the self-service replacement for Set/Get Parameters. For most customers, their main concern is the use of Default Values compared to classic Get/Set Parameters.  For this refer to the following blog posts:

  • SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA â€“ Synchronizing Default Values with Set/Get Parameters
  • Applying User Defaults in SAP S/4HANA

Default values includes options for key users to set up default value combinations for their teams. Refer to SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA â€“ Yes Key Users can set Default Values for other Users.

 

Custom-built Launchpad plug-ins

Where possible replace custom plug-ins with similar standard features.  This reduces on-going maintenance effort/cost & minimizes upgrade impacts.  For example, replace a plug-in to show the system/client in the shell header with the standard System Information Bar.

Where you want to retain custom plug-ins, refer to the latest advice in the SAP Help SAP Fiori launchpad > Developer Guide > Extending the Launchpad.

 

Remember your administrators

Many administration tools for your technical team require SAP Fiori apps, so make sure you are including their needs in your assessment.

Several SAP Business Roles are provided as starting points. For example:

  • Administrator (SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR)
  • Extensibility Specialist (SAP_BR_EXTENSIBILITY_SPEC)
  • Fiori Foundation Administration role generated by the task list SAP_FIORI_FOUNDATION_S4 task list task â€œGenerate Fiori Foundation rolesâ€.

Hint: By default the Fiori Foundation Administration role is a composite role with the id Z_FIORI_FOUNDATION_ADMIN.

There are major shifts to be aware of in:

  1. app activation
  2. launchpad content and layout maintenance

App Activation

To minimize effort, avoid activating apps one by one!  The SAP Fiori rapid activation process is long-established and has been improved over several releases.  It provides support for efficient activation of apps by SAP Business Role, by custom business role, and by business catalog. 

  • For SAP Business Roles it makes exploration simpler by supporting generation of test users, and assignment of existing users. It provides pre-/post- activation prerequisites for special roles.
  • For custom business roles,  it simplifies authorization maintenance for security administrators by generating authorizations based on content assignments and SU24 authorizations defaults for app services. Hint: You can control which assignments are generated via the Launchpad Configuration Parameters.
  • For business catalogs - the smallest grouping of apps - you can respect the segregation of duties within the technical team.  Catalog activation is also integrated into the Launchpad Content Manager (Client-Specific) for ease of managing delta changes.

For an introduction refer to: 

  • SAP Help - SAP Fiori Overview - Rapid Activation of SAP Fiori 
  • SAP Note 2902673 - Rapid Activation for SAP Fiori in SAP S/4HANA - Overview
  • You will find further resources in the section Learnings to get you started.

Example process to activate apps by catalog respecting Segregation of Duties across the technical team

 

 

Launchpad content and layout management

Intent-based navigation works as before. That is an intent consists of a logical Semantic Object + Action pair, that can flexibly be used to point to any UI content supported by the SAP Fiori launchpad.

However, there have been several major shifts in launchpad content and layout maintenance. Refer to: SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA â€“ Upgrade Faster â€“ Major shifts in SAP Fiori implementation

Target Mappings and Tiles are no longer separate entities. They are combined into Launchpad App Descriptor Items (LADIs).

  • A LADI combines a target mapping with one or more related tiles.
  • LADIs avoids the risk of misalignment when assigning tiles and target mappings.
  • You can choose which tile to display when maintaining your page

Hint: If you have separated your catalogs for tiles versus your catalogs for target mappings, use the technical catalog migration tool in your system conversion to correct your design.

Catalogs follow a 2-level design that is supported and enforced by the tooling. That is:

  • Cross-client technical catalogs that hold original LADIs
  • Client-specific business catalogs the reference LADIs from the technical catalogs.
  • Business catalogs are assigned to (composite or single, SAP or custom) business roles

Technical catalogs can hold many LADIs. They are essentially a container of LADIs.

Business catalogs typically reference a limited number of LADIs, that are assigned to a business role together, such as the smallest Segregation of Duties combination.

Hint: If you have a single-level catalog design, use your system conversion to correct your design. If you have assigned business roles to technical catalogs, use your system conversion to correct your design.

You can use the migration tool for technical catalogs to move your tiles/target mappings to LADIs and align your catalog design to the required 2-level design.

Refer to:

  • SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA - Technical Catalog Migration â€“ Why and Getting Ready for Migration
  • SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA - Technical Catalog Migration â€“ How the migration process works

Hint: The technical catalog migration has been further improved in SAP S/4HANA 2025 to make this easier.

The Launchpad Designer is deprecated. You will move to new tooling for managing launchpad content, including:

  • Launchpad App Manager
  • Launchpad Content Manager Client-Specific
  • Launchpad Content Aggregator - read-only view of launchpad content
  • Manage Launchpad Spaces
  • Manage Launchpad Pages
  • Overview of Roles, Spaces, and Pages â€“ read-only view of launchpad layouts
  • Launchpad Configuration Parameters
  • Role-based Launchpad Configuration Parameters via transaction /UI2/FLP_PROF_CONF (new with SAP S/4HANA 2025)

All these tools support both single and composite business roles. You will find these tools are assigned to the Fiori Foundation Administration role generated as part of rapid activation task list SAP_FIORI_FOUNDATION_S4 task Generate Fiori Foundation roles.

 

Watchpoints when coming from SAP Fiori in SAP Enterprise Portal

If you are coming from SAP Fiori deployed in SAP Enterprise Portal, there are some additional watchpoints.

1. Select your SAP Build Work Zone edition.

You should compare features available for the central launchpad on SAP Build Work Zone standard edition versus advanced edition. If your aim is to create a full business site then advanced edition may suit your needs better.

2. The Universal Work List moves to SAP Fiori app F0862 My Inbox.

Most tasks (work items) will be automatically transitioned.  However, you may want to improve the visualization. If you have configured your Universal Worklist with dynamic columns you will need to explore the extension options in F0862 My Inbox.

3. Pay attention to navigation via OBN

OBN (Object-Based Naivgation) is specific to the SAP Enterprise Portal. Based on customer experiences, you may have some issues getting existing OBN to work in the SAP Fiori launchpad. SAP Fiori launchpad uses intent-based navigation. There are several workarounds already available. For example:

  • SAP Note 3254771 - Failed to resolve object based navigation target in Fiori Launchpad 
  • 3475684 - OBN Navigation Failure within Side Panel App using SAP FIORI System Entry
  • 2934443 - Object Based Navigation in standalone scenario fails
  • 1378659 - NWBC known issues & what to check when opening a ticket

4. Use of LPD_CUST for creating a report hierarchy is still supported. However, you must NOT use LPD_CUST for launchpad content navigation.  

To integrate launchpad content with the SAP Fiori launchpad, you must reconfigure your content using the Launchpad App Manager. Refer to SAP Note 2614740 - Fiori Launchpad Designer - Usage of Application Type "SAP Fiori App using LPD_CUST" in Target Mapping Configuration is Deprecated

 

Reintroducing your upgraded launchpad to your business users

You will find some tips to get you started in the following blog posts:

  • SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA â€“ Pro-tips for demonstrating SAP Fiori â€“ Organizing your My Home page
  • SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA â€“ Pro-tips for demonstrating SAP Fiori â€“ Navigate with confidence

 

Learnings to get you started

Learning Course: Learning the Basics of SAP Fiori

SAP Fiori architecture:

  • Blog SAP Fiori deployment options and SAP Fiori front-end server strategy - UPDATE 2025
  • Whitepaper SAP Fiori deployment options and system landscape recommendations
  • Whitepaper Moving from Standalone to Embedded Deployment in SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA

Learning Videos (how-to guides):

  • Activating SAP Fiori Launchpad Using SAP Fiori Foundation Task List
  • Patching SAP Fiori (SAPUI5)
  • Configuring the SAP Fiori Launchpad for SAP S/4HANA
  • Bringing Apps Onto SAP Fiori Launchpad for SAP S/4HANA Cloud and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition
  • Activating SAP Fiori Content in Custom Business Roles in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA
  • Creating SAP Fiori Launchpad Layouts for Custom Business Roles
  • Adapting the UI of List Report Apps with SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA

Transport considerations:

  • Whitepaper SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA - Rapid Activation Transport Move to Production Strategy

 

Whatâ€™s behind all these changes in SAP Fiori

SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA reflects the changes over the last 10 years (since 2015) in:

  • business innovations,
  • changes in architecture and technical practices to support business innovations,
  • and in the need for Clean Core approaches to mitigate the increasing speed of change.

Refer to whitepaper: Clean core extensibility for SAP S/4HANA Cloud

By moving to SAP S/4HANA, your architecture changes:

  • For most customers, you will move your SAP Fiori front-end server from standalone to embedded deployment mode. Refer to SAP Fiori deployment options and SAP Fiori front-end server strategy - UPDATE 2025 and whitepaper SAP Fiori deployment options and system landscape recommendations
  • You need to consider the impact of cloud services and solutions. For example, you may want to: add the generative AI digital assistant SAP Joule; add a central launchpad via SAP Build Work Zone; consolidate approvals to a unified inbox via SAP Task Center; add process automation through SAP Build; and/or add digital adoption features via SAP WalkMe.

 

Hint: Embedded deployment mode is the most efficient and recommended architecture for SAP S/4HANA. The rapid activation tools and most SAP Fiori support tools either require embedded mode or are optimized for embedded mode.

  • You can transition your current SAP Fiori front-end server to embedded deployment mode. Refer to whitepaper Moving from Standalone to Embedded Deployment in SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA.
  • Alternatively, if in SAP Business Suite (SAP ECC) you only use a handful of apps and are willing to accept the loss of user personalizations, you can simply install fresh on embedded mode, and redeploy any custom- or partner-built apps and features.

 

By moving to SAP S/4HANA, the following technical changes apply:

  • The database model changes from being based on ABAP Dictionary tables to ABAP CDS View Entities based on the HANA Database
  • For those coming from Suite on HANA, HANA Live apps were replaced by apps based on ABAP CDS Views.
  • The SAPUI5 version lifts to the latest long-term maintenance version for SAP S/4HANA
  • Programming models for frontend development shift to match the SAPUI5 version â€“ for example the SAP Fiori Flexible Programming Model for SAP Fiori elements
  • The programming model for building & deploying apps changes from SEGW (based on OData V2) to RESTful ABAP Programming Model (RAP â€“ based on OData V4 and aligned to Cloud Application Programming Model)

 

SAP Fiori elements building blocks improve the consistency of apps for business users and speed the development of custom-built apps by reducing the need for freestyle SAPUI5 apps

 

You will want to gain quick wins from the vast amount of available business content of your target SAP S/4HANA release:

  • A range of new and improved launchpad features become available to you
  • New predefined SAP Fiori apps â€“ as listed SAP Fiori apps reference library

SAP S/4HANA brings more than 3.5K SAP Fiori apps and this is still growing with each SAP S/4HANA release and feature pack.  Plus, another 11.5K classic UIs are provided as pre-configured launchpad content. This content help you give all business users a unified web- and cloud- centric entry point through the SAP Fiori launchpad.

You may have additional business user needs to consider. For example:

  • Central launchpad on SAP Build Work Zone
  • Mobile launchpad via SAP Mobile Start
  • Unified inbox via SAP Task Center
  • Advanced innovations, such as SAP Business AI including SAP Joule

Refer to SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA â€“ Minimum UX you need for SAP Business AI and Clean Core. Hint: For on-premise customers considering SAP Business AI, refer to SAP Note 3632703 - Enabling Joule for On-Premise systems

And last but not least you need to consider how you apply Clean Core to reduce future upgrade effort, so you can take on innovations faster.  Especially:

  • The way you extend your SAP S/4HANA solution moves into SAP Fiori. For example, key user adaptations and related SAP Business Roles such as Extensibility Specialist (SAP_ BR_EXTENSIBILITY_SPEC).
  • The way you administer your system moves into SAP Fiori. For example, transport of key user extensions, monitoring of workflows, application jobs, application logs, and managing search models. Quick start by turning on SAP Business Roles such as Administrator. (SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR).

 

Becoming a SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA guru

Youâ€™ll find much more on our  SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA topic page

entry.title: SAP in the Leaders category at the 2025 IDC MarketScape for utility meter data management systems
entry.content:
Please find below the SAP evaluation from IDC MarketScape: Worldwide Utility Meter Data Management Systems 2025 Vendor Assessment:

SAP serves clients across more than 180 countries with over 105,000 employees worldwide. Its utilities division delivers digital solutions to hundreds of live MDMS customers, encompassing electricity, gas, water, and heat sectors, with implementations from small municipal networks to multi-million endpoint portfolios. SAP S/4HANA Utilities integrates core utility functionsâ€”including energy data management, device management, billing, and customer engagementâ€”into a unified software suite designed for deployment at scale and with multi-commodity, multi-tenant support.

The Energy Data Management and Device Management modules within SAP S/4HANA Utilities provide end-to-end capabilities for collecting, validating, storing, and managing both interval and discrete meter data. These modules support two-way communication with a diverse range of smart meters and head-end systems, enabling asynchronous automated meter readings, remote connect/disconnect, firmware management, and real-time event handling. Advanced VEE functions ensure near real-time data quality, compliance, and readiness for billing, settlement, or analytics, with customizable rules for anomaly detection and automated exception handling. SAPâ€™s high-volume architecture scales to billions of meter readings, using batch and parallel processing, robust audit and version controls, and granular role-based security to deliver performance and reliability for large utility deployments.

Distinctive capabilities include vendor-agnostic device modelling, multi-commodity management under a single system, flexible integration for third-party AMI and IoT devices, and support for complex business requirements such as TOU tariffs, prepayment, and regulatory reporting. SAP S/4HANA Utilities features embedded analytics and operational dashboardsâ€”powered by SAP Fiori and Analytics Cloudâ€”supporting consumption and asset analysis, anomaly prediction, KPI monitoring, and demand forecasting. The system integrates directly with billing, contract management, and financial processes, facilitating seamless meter-to-cash and regulatory compliance workflows. Utilities can visualize customer insights, consumption patterns, and field operations through interactive dashboards and mobile/web portals.

SAP delivers S/4HANA Utilities via multiple deployment models including on-premises, hybrid, private cloud, andâ€”planned for wider rolloutâ€”public cloud SaaS. Currently, 80% of live deployments are on-premises, with increasing momentum toward private and hybrid cloud configurations and emerging public cloud solutions. Commercial packaging is modular, with options for perpetual licenses, subscription models based on meter points managed, and outcome-based options. Trial periods are standard and SAP Value Engineering tools support ROI justification for technology investments and transformation initiatives.

Services and support are structured in tiered offeringsâ€”from basic to premium and mission-critical levelsâ€”providing live chat, virtual assistant, 24/7 expert access, and proactive lifecycle management. Dedicated customer success managers and solution architects guide project implementation, process optimization, and regulatory alignment. Knowledge bases, online communities, and training hubs complement peer engagement and feedback via customer councils, shaping feature development and

product strategy. SAPâ€™s support coverage spans over 10 languages, with compliance maintained through regular software updates and professional services across more than 140 jurisdictions.

The partner ecosystem for S/4HANA Utilities spans global SIs (e.g., Accenture, Capgemini, Deloitte, Wipro), smart grid OEMs and solution providers (e.g., Itron, Landis+Gyr, Sensus), utility-software and analytics providers (e.g., SEW, NET2GRID, C3 AI, Bidgely) and cloud infrastructure vendors (e.g., AWS, Microsoft, Google Cloud). Integration is facilitated through SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), with open APIs supporting extensibility, data sharing, and fast onboarding of specialized partner solutions for outage management, DER integration, demand response, and network optimization.

Innovation at SAP is organized around AI enablement, cloud-native architectures, and process automation. Recent enhancements include AI-driven Joule for anomaly detection, consumption forecasting, automated validation, and predictive asset maintenance. The roadmap prioritizes generative AI for agentic workflows, natural language processing for customer engagement, and large language model integration via BTP. The systemâ€™s flexibility supports distributed intelligence at the edge through partner extensions and SAP IoT capabilities, positioning utilities to manage digitalization, energy transition, regulatory change, and new market requirements efficiently and securely.

Strengths

  • SAP has a presence in utilities in every continent and almost every country, delivering digital solutions to hundreds of live MDMS customers. This makes the extent and diversity of its customer base in terms of subindustries, client size, and geographic footprint vast and referenceability high.
  • From a features and functionalities perspective, SAPâ€™s Energy Data Management and Device Management modules support smart and interval meters as well as advanced metering infrastructure with a comprehensive range of capabilities covering large commercial and industrial clients, including Field Service & Work Order Integration, Time-of-Day and Prepayment Operations, Consumer Engagement & Energy Management and Predictive modelling.
  • SAP solutions are integrated by design, sharing a common technology platform, a consistent look and feel, and a customer-friendly user experience and UI, thanks also to SAP Fiori.

Challenges

  • Customers indicate that one area for improvement with SAP is customer service, with some users reporting challenges in receiving timely and effective support for their needs. Feedback suggests that customer service experiences can vary, and addressing support responsiveness could enhance overall customer satisfaction with SAPâ€™s offerings.
  • When it comes to pricing models, SAPâ€™s offering is currently limited to â€œsubscription based on meter points managedâ€ for its SaaS deployments. It does not provide alternatives such as user/seat licensing or consumption-based pricing, which constrains flexibility for customers with varying usage patterns or organizational structures.

entry.title: Innovating for a Circular Future: Whatâ€™s new in Waste and Recycling in S/4HANA 2025
entry.content:
As the world continues to place increasing emphasis on sustainability â€“ waste management and recycling have taken center stage in the journey towards a circular economy. At SAP, we are committed to support this shift and provide continuous innovation in our Waste and Recycling solution. In this blog, Iâ€™m excited to share some of the key innovations and features with the latest release of S/4HANA 2025 FPS0.

1. Laying the foundation with CDS Views

Core Data Services (CDS) Views have emerged as a cornerstone of modern SAP system architecture, enabling streamlined data modelling and real-time access to relevant information. In the context of SAP Waste and Recycling, CDS Views provide the foundation for efficient data management and analytics by centralizing and structuring data across various modules. This not only simplifies reporting and operational decision-making but also paves the way for more advanced capabilities, such as analytics and integrations. Some of the CDS views are also available from the previous release (2023).

  • Waste Disposal Orders

SAP waste disposal orders are core documents used in SAP S/4HANA for Waste and Recycling to manage and track the collection and transport of waste on specific planned routes. The order includes a header (route, date, start time) and line items (customer, contract, service type, address). For further information, refer - Analysis and Overview of Waste Disposal Orders

  • Weighing Documents

When vehicles carrying waste arrive at, or leave, a facility such as a landfill, incineration plant, or recycling center, they are weighed using a connected weighbridge, and these results are recorded directly in SAP S/4HANA as weighing transactions. These transactions are directly linked to waste disposal orders or contracts ensuring that the actual quantities collected, delivered, or processed are precisely documented and associated with the correct customer, contract, and order item. This ensures transparency for billing, regulatory compliance, and operational analysis. For further information, refer - Weighing Transactions â€“ Multi Item Weighing

  • Containers Management

Container allocation forms the central component that binds the technical equipment information (containers) with the relevant service information (waste materials, service types, frequency, start dates etc. For further information, refer Containers Tracking

  • Route Management

CDS views for Routes provide information related to different routes based on region, service types, service areas, container categories etc. You can also enable the retrieval of route identification with equipment, service number item details with its service location, interval type, and category, and resources related to the route. For further details pls refer -  Routes

  • Waste Sales Contracts

This CDS view is for the waste specific sales contracts. It provides a view of the contracts which are active and have containers allocated to their premise. For further details, refer Waste & Recycling Sales Contracts

2. Tare Based Weighing

Tare weight or vehicle weight can be maintained in the vehicle/equipment master data. Multi Item weighing transaction will automatically consider & populate the tare weight maintained in the master data to arrive at the â€œNETâ€ weight. This eliminates the need for a second weighing of the empty vehicle to complete & post the weighing transaction thereby improving the operational efficiency. For further details, refer - Tare Weight Auto-Populate

3. Introducing Output Management and Control within Weighbridge Application

Output Management and Control in SAP S/4HANA provides a standardised framework for manging the creation, formatting and distribution of business documents such as invoices, delivery notes across different channels like print, email and electronic formats. By enabling the Weighbridge application to leverage this standard framework, we bring the same level of consistency, control and automation within waste and recycling facilities.

For further details refer - Integration with S/4 Output Management

4. Enabling Real -Time Insights with Weighing Overview Fiori App

With this release, we introduce our first analytical Fiori app providing a unified and intuitive interface to all Weighing records that allow users to monitor both internal and external weighing records. Supervisors and planners can now visualize trends, identify bottlenecks and take timely actions driving greater transparency, agility and operational excellence.

For further details refer - Weighing Overview

entry.title: Effortless SAPUI5 Patch Management: Introducing the New SAPUI5 Runtime Repository
entry.content:
For years, the MIME repository has been the standard location for storing SAPUI5 runtime artifacts for SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition. In contrast, the S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition retrieves SAPUI5 from the cloud CDN. Although the MIME repository has served its purpose, many customers working with SAPUI5, especially system operators installing new SAPUI5 patches, face common challenges. These include poor performance, numerous manual steps, issues with transports, and risk of inconsistent states.

The good news is that SAP introduces the SAPUI5 Runtime Repository with the release of SAP S/4HANA 2025. This modern replacement overcomes these challenges and prepares you for the next generation of SAPUI5. To ensure efficiency for all customers, downports to all maintained lower releases are available, except for SAP S/4HANA 1809 using SAPUI5 1.38. You can access this repository through SAP Notes containing transport-based correction instructions (TCIs).

Let's explore how this new repository significantly enhances your workflow.

Performance Where It Matters

  • MIME Repository: SAPUI5 patch updates can take up to 2 hours. Loading debug-sources with sap-ui-debug=true can take up to 10 minutes.
  • SAPUI5 Runtime Repository: Patch upgrades are approximately 20 times faster. During runtime, loading debug sources also occurs about 20 times faster. These improvements ensure smoother operations and faster response times.

From Complexity to Simplicity

  • MIME Repository: Handles more than 70,000 individual ABAP objects. This volume poses a risk of errors and inconsistent updates.
  • SAPUI5 Runtime Repository: All runtime content is bundled into just one ABAP object. This approach guarantees consistent updates and reduces operational risks.

Automation First

  • MIME Repository: Updates rely on custom, manual procedures, which increases the maintenance effort.
  • SAPUI5 Runtime Repository: Uses SAP TCI Notes and comes with an automated process specifically for SAP S/4HANA cloud operations. This makes updates easier and more reliable.

Zero Downtime Deployments

  • MIME Repository: No support for zero-downtime deployments. This limitation might cause interruptions during system upgrades.
  • SAPUI5 Runtime Repository: Fully supports online deployment with zero downtime. This feature ensures that SAPUI5 content remains continuously available, even during system upgrades.

Safe, Standardized Rollbacks

  • MIME Repository: Reverting patches can be error-prone, often requiring manual fixes and risking inconsistent system states.
  • SAPUI5 Runtime Repository: Reverting SAPUI5 patches is fully supported. Runtime content is delivered as a single ABAP object, and the update process integrates with TCIs. Rollbacks are straightforward, consistent, and safe. This approach simplifies the validation of new patches: if issues arise, you can reliably revert to the previous stable state without lengthy manual intervention or risking inconsistencies across systems.

Future-Proof 

  • MIME Repository: Not compatible with multiple SAPUI5 versions.
  • SAPUI5 Runtime Repository: Supports multiple SAPUI5 versions in parallel, making it ready for the future while ensuring backward compatibility.

Here's an overview of all the improvements:

Why This Matters

The move from MIME Repository to the new SAPUI5 Runtime Repository isnâ€™t just a technical upgrade â€” itâ€™s a significant step toward:

  • Faster and safer patch updates.
  • Reduced operational effort.
  • Continuous availability.
  • Future compatibility.

If your organization uses on-premise landscapes and works with SAPUI5, it's time to embrace this change: the SAPUI5 Runtime Repository becomes automatically available with the current SAP S/4HANA 2025 release and in the latest support packages of all maintained SAP S/4HANA versions except SAP S/4HANA 1809.

Even if you do not want to upgrade to a new support package, you can still use the SAPUI5 runtime repository by installing SAP Note 3599156. If you have hesitated to install a new SAPUI5 patch, now is the time to try the new procedure and benefit from its efficacy and ease. Installing the latest SAPUI5 patches ensures your applications run efficiently today and are prepared for the future.

entry.title: SAP numbering again â€¦ letâ€™s jump!
entry.content:
Itâ€™s been a while, and I thought I was grown out of this, but I canâ€™t get out of the habit.
I wonder why software component SAP BASIS has jumped up to version 8.16 recently.

Reminds me of my old blog posts on SAP numbering:

  • Why SAP ERP 6.0 EHP6 contains SAP BASIS 7.31 - SAP Community
  • SAP versioning, part 2 (why EHP7 contains SAP APPL... - SAP Community

Product version SAP S/4HANA 2025 (in short: 2025) is available since October 2025, and it contains software component version SAP BASIS 8.16. I must have been inattentive for a moment, since I was still considering it in the number range â€œ7-somethingâ€. OK, kids grow up and get older, but S/4HANA 2023 was based on 7.58 â€“ now it is on 8.16. This is a jump, isnâ€™t it?

Subtracting 16 from 58 provides an interesting but misleading answer. Of course, you already see the real reason: my inattentive phase took too long, the distance between 2023 and 2025 is longer than before. SAP S/4HANA (Cloud Private Edition and on-prem) switched from a yearly to a bi-yearly release cycle, with three Feature Package Stacks in-between. But SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition is delivered every quarter, and with this, it is eating up the numbers for the SAP BASIS versions.
As this is sorted out, let us look onto another component: the kernel. SAP Kernel 9.16 is used for 2025. Not a typo: SAP Kernel 9.16 and SAP Basis 8.16. 2023 uses SAP Kernel 7.93, and a move from 7.93 to 9.16 is even a bigger jump than the one SAP BASIS did!

Again, my inattention was probably the reason for my astonishment: I ignored SAP Business ByDesign (in short: ByD), another ABAP-based business solution from SAP that uses SAP Kernel and SAP BASIS. ByD has eaten up the kernel numbers in the 8-range, so 2025 jumped to â€œ9-somethingâ€. Jump 2 is clarified.

Letâ€™s see what comes next to challenge my numbering skills.
